{{primary|date=February 2015}} '''Opera Europa''' is the international service organisation for professional opera companies and opera festivals in Europe. It is incorporated in Brussels as a not-for-profit organisation. With roots going back to 1995, Opera Europa gained its present format and name in 2002, on the merger of the European Opera Network and the Eurolyrica associations.Opera Europa website. [http://opera-europa.org/view.asp?id=340 The beginnings of Opera Europa: a short chronicle] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110823191438/http://opera-europa.org/view.asp?id=340 |date=August 23, 2011 }} It had 160 member companies in 40 different countries as at May 2016.Opera Europa website. [http://opera-europa.org/en/members Members list]. Retrieved 3 May 2016. ==Activities== For the benefit of its member companies, it runs forums, databases, a quarterly newsletter, and twice-yearly conferences, and offers reciprocal membership benefits with [[Opera America]].Opera Europa website. [http://opera-europa.org/en/about-us/intro-to-oe About Us pages] ===European Opera Days=== Opera Europa co-ordinates the annual European Opera Days when opera companies across Europe open their doors to the general public, with opera house tours, open rehearsals, talks and special events (both in and outside the conventional spaces). The first European Opera Days were held in 2007, and since then have taken place each year on the weekend closest to the EU's [[Europe Day]], 9 May.[http://operadays.eu European Opera Days website] Retrieved 13 Aug 2011. ===The Opera Platform=== Opera Europa is the lead partner behind The Opera Platform, a service launched in May 2015 to offer free live streams of operas via the web. The three-year project to stream one free production every month received half of its 3.9 million euro budget from the European Union's [[Creative Europe]] programme, the other half coming from the 15 opera companies providing the content. The Franco-German TV network [[Arte]] is providing the technological platform.{{Citation | last = Minder | first = Raphael | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/13/arts/international/europe-sees-free-streaming-of-opera-as-a-way-to-stay-relevant.html | title = Europe Sees Free Streaming of Opera as a Way to Stay Relevant | newspaper = The New York Times | date = 12 May 2015 }} The Opera Platform won the Accessibility category in the 2016 edition of the [[International Opera Awards]].[http://www.operaawards.org/archive/2016/ 2016 winners], International Opera Awards. Retrieved 22 October 2016 ===European Opera-directing Prize (EOP)=== In collaboration with the [[Camerata Nuova e.V.]] in [[Wiesbaden]], Opera Europa supports a biennial competition, the European Opera-directing Prize (EOP, in German: Europäischen Opernregie-Preis) for young opera directors and design teams up to the age of 35. Competition is fierce with more than 200 teams applying in 2009.Camerata Nuova website. [http://www.camerata-nuova.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=10&Itemid=13 Was ist der EOP?] {{de icon}} The winning team receive prize money of 35,000 euros, but perhaps more importantly have their production mounted by a European opera company, receiving mentoring and support for this process.Camerata Nuova website.[http://www.camerata-nuova.com/european-opera-directing-prize-eop/ Overview in English] {| class="wikitable" !Year !Opera !Winning team !Premiere !Sponsoring company |- |2001||[[Fidelio]] ([[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]])||Matthias Lutz (dir),
Julia Hansen (design)||style="text-align:right"|29 Apr 2002||[[Hessisches Staatstheater Wiesbaden|Hessisches Staatstheater]], Wiesbaden |- |2003||[[Hans Heiling]] ([[Heinrich Marschner|Marschner]])||Andreas May (dir),
David König (design)||style="text-align:right"|28 Feb 2004||[[Opéra national du Rhin]], Strasbourg |- |2005||[[La Cenerentola|La cenerentola]] ([[Gioachino Rossini|Rossini]])||[[Thaddeus Strassberger]] (dir,sets),
Mattie Ullrich (costumes)||style="text-align:right"|22 Apr 2006||[[Opera Ireland]], Dublin |- |2007||[[Rusalka]] ([[Antonín Dvořák|Dvořák]])||Johannes Gleim (dir),
Daniela Juckel (design)||style="text-align:right"|30 Mar 2008||[[Latvian National Opera]], Riga |- |2009||[[La finta giardiniera]] ([[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]])||Anna Dirckinck-Holmfeld (dir),
Sibylle Wallum (design)||style="text-align:right"|1 Apr 2010||[[Bern Theatre|Stadttheater Bern]] |- |2011||[[I Capuleti e i Montecchi]] ([[Vincenzo Bellini|Bellini]])||Sam Brown (dir),
Annemarie Woods (design)||style="text-align:right"|27 Sep 2012||[[As.Li.Co.]], Como and tour |- |2013||[[Cavalleria rusticana]] ([[Pietro Mascagni|Mascagni]]) and [[Pagliacci]] ([[Ruggero Leoncavallo|Leoncavallo]])||''Prize not awarded''||||[[Stadttheater Klagenfurt]] |- |2015||[[Weiße Rose (opera)|Weiße Rose]] ([[Udo Zimmermann]])||''Joint first prize:''
Niki Ellinidou (dir),
Nefeli Myrtidi (design)||style="text-align:right"|October 2016||[[Cologne Opera|Oper Köln]] |- |,,||,,||''Joint first prize:''
Anna Drescher (dir),
Hudda Chukri (design)||style="text-align:right"|4 Nov 2016||{{illm|Theater Orchester Biel Solothurn|de||}} |- |2016||[[La traviata]] ([[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]])||Andrea Bernard (dir)
Elena Beccaro, Alberto Beltrame (design)||style="text-align:right"|October 2017||{{illm|Festival Verdi|it||}}, [[Teatro Giuseppe Verdi]], Busseto |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== *[http://opera-europa.org Opera Europa] website *[http://www.camerata-nuova.com Camerata Nuova e.V., Wiesbaden] website {{de icon}} [[Category:Opera organizations]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1995]] [[Category:Music organisations based in Belgium]]

'''Pacific Resident Theatre (PRT)''' is a 501(c)(3) non-profit theatre company located at 707 Venice Boulevard in [[Venice, California]]. It was founded as an actors cooperative in Venice's arts district in 1985 and is dedicated to producing both classic<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1993-08-18/entertainment/ca-24823_1_pacific-resident-theatre-ensemble ''Los Angeles Times'' Theater Review: A fearless, massive ''Ondine'' enchants despite complexity, August 18, 1993]</ref> and little known plays,<ref>[http://www.theatermania.com/los-angeles-theater/news/01-2005/los-angeles-spotlight-january-2005_5447.html ''Los Angeles Spotlight'': Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill's seldom performed 1929 musical ''Happy End'', January 1, 2005]</ref> as well as works by new authors.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2006/may/19/entertainment/et-stage19.5 ''Los Angeles Times'' Theater Review: Motherhood tips over a man's world, World premiere production of Alex Peabody’s ''Keeping Faith'', May 19, 2006]</ref> The company has received over 90 awards<ref>[http://findlocal.latimes.com/listings/pacific-resident-theatre-venice ''Los Angeles Times'' Concert Halls & Theaters: Pacific Resident Theatre]</ref> including awards from the [[Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle Award|L.A. Drama Critics Circle]],<ref>[http://www.goldstar.com/venues/venice-ca/pacific-resident-theatre Goldstar National: Pacific Resident Theatre]</ref> [[Drama-Logue Award|Drama-Logue]], the [[NAACP Image Award|NAACP]], the [[LA Weekly Theater Award|LA Weekly]] and [[Back Stage Garland Awards|Garland]].<ref>[http://www.backstage.com/bso/esearch/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=682408 Backstage, The Actors Resource: Garlands Toast - Best in the West]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

'''Pavel Yahoravich Marozau''' (Belarusian: ''Павел Ягоравiч Марозаў'', born on October 11, 1978 in [[Minsk]]) is a [[Belarus|Belarusian]] and [[Estonia|Estonian]] civic activist, media manager and web producer.
==Education and early life== Pavel graduated from Belarusian State University of Economics (BSUE) with major in Banking (2000), got a master's degree from BSUE in Finance and Credit (2004), and then obtained master's degree in Political Science from [[European Humanities University]] (2004).
Since 1998 he had been actively involved into volunteering with Belarusian office of [[Service Civil International]] (SCI), from 2000 till 2003 he was a member of the Financial Councilors Committee of this organization. After graduation he was working in Priorbank (part of [[Raiffeisen Zentralbank|Raiffeisen Holding]], Austria), then shifting to IT business and realization of the Fostering Opportunities in Belarusian [[Green politics|Green Movement]] project. In 2004 he founded a branch of local [[Third Way (centrism)|Third Way]] community.
==Civic involvement and political excile== In 2005-2006 Marozau participated in [[Belarusian presidential election, 2006|Belarusian presidential election]] as a member of the opposition candidate's [[Alyaksandr Kazulin]] team. Simultaneously, he got under politically motivated persecutions by the Belarusian authorities for producing satirical animated films casting president [[Lukashenko]], being accused of slandering the Belarusian president. Since late 2006 he has been in political emigration in Estonia after Belarusian authorities’ attempt to arrest him in Minsk.
In the same year Marozau established and took charge of the Valgevene Uus Tee civic organization in Tallinn (Estonia), which aims to develop critical thinking skills of young people in the post-Soviet countries and carries out multiple cultural and media projects in the Baltics, Belarus, Ukraine and Russia.
In late 2014 Marozau founded Russian-language web television [[ARU TV]] aimed to counteract Kremlin propaganda in Eastern Europe. In addition, he is the organizer of the RUBYCON annual conference for Russian and Belarussian pro-democratic experts and journalists conducted in partnership with the Estonian MFA.
==Expertise== Pavel Marozau is a concept author and implementer of more than 50 projects in the fields of civic activism, information, and culture. He has delivered a number of lectures on situation in East Europe at Woodrow Wilson Center, Kennan Institute, European Doctoral College (Strasbourg), European College of Tartu University, German Marshall Fund, the Heritage Foundation (Washington, D.C.), Carnegie Center (Moscow), Congress Center (Geneva), and other organizations. In addition, he is an expert at [[Atlantic Council|Atlantic Council’s]] DisinfoPortal.org – website aimed to track the Kremlin’s disinformation campaigns abroad.
Marozau is an alumnus of the PACT Leadership Institute (U.S.), Fletcher School (U.S.), and Maastricht University (Germany-Netherlands) programs. He holds MS in Finance and MA in Political Science.
==Personal life== In 2011 Pavel got married to Olga-Anastasia Marozava.
==External links== * Adam Schrader. Belarusian Cartoons at Cairo Human Rights Film Fest - [http://bikyamasr.com/?p=6560] * Larissa Eltsefon, Blair Ruble. Pursuing Democracy in Belarus Through Satiric Media: Samizdat for the Modern Era - [http://www.wilsoncenter.org/index.cfm?topic_id=1424&fuseaction=topics.event_summary&event_id=554768] * Bloggers for Freedom and Internet's New Frontiers: Defending Democracy in Cyberspace - Part 5 (video) - [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BYWdNG4_M9E&feature=channel_page] * Fabien Miard. Mobile Phones as a Tool for Civil Resistance. Case studies from Serbia and Belarus - [http://www.digiactive.org/wp-content/uploads/research3_miard.pdf] * ALDE Newspaper. Belarus : looking for a solution - [http://www.alde-pace.org/_uploads/1223974045_NEWSLETTER4_2008.pdf] * Radio Free Liberty. Independent Belarusian Media Targeted By Authorities - [http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1347772.html]
==Sites== * The Third Way - [http://www.3dway.org] * ARU TV - [http://www.aru1.tv] * Facebook - [http://ru-ru.facebook.com/pavel.mor?_fb_noscript=1] * Cartoons - [https://www.youtube.com/lukashenkocartoons] * Narod.Lu - [https://web.archive.org/web/20100130231609/http://www.narod.lu/]

'''Penguin Composition Rules''' were the guidelines written by typographer [[Jan Tschichold]] for use in composing the pages and typography of [[Penguin Books]]. The rules were embodied in a four-page booklet of typographic instructions for editors and compositors. The booklet includes headings for various aspects of composition: Text Composition; Indenting of Paragraphs; Punctuation Marks and Spelling; Capitals, Small Capitals, and Italics; References and Footnotes; Folios; The Printing of Plays; The Printing of Poetry; Make-up.
Beyond this specific set of guidelines, Tschichold made further changes to Penguin's graphic standards. Penguin is well known for its standardized book covers and formats, as well as the diversity of the standards.<ref>The seeming contradiction between standardization and diversity is explained by the vast numbers of books produced by Penguin over many years.</ref>
==Jan Tschichold and Penguin== Penguin Books was founded by Allen Lane in 1935.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.penguin.co.uk/static/cs/uk/0/aboutus/history.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105152710/http://www.penguin.co.uk/static/cs/uk/0/aboutus/history.html |archivedate=2013-11-05 |df= }}</ref> The basic look of Penguin was established before Lane brought Tschichold to Penguin in the late 1940s as head of typography and production. Tschichold was in England at Penguin between 1947 and 1949 before returning to Switzerland.
Tschichold's standardization of Penguin covers essentially took existing elements and refined them visually and refined their arrangement. Under Tschichold the covers included the use of [[Eric Gill|Eric Gill's]] [[Gill Sans]] typeface, which he was careful to have spaced evenly. According to Tschichold establishing this quality was not immediately embraced by the compositors; “Every day I had to wade through miles of corrections (often ten books daily). I had a rubber stamp made: ‘Equalize letter-spaces according to their visual value.’ It was totally ignored; the hand compositors continued to space out the capitals on title-pages (where optical spacing is essential) with spaces of equal thickness.”<ref name="doubleday">Richard Doubleday, "[http://www.dis.uia.mx/conference/2005/HTMs-PDFs/PenguinBooks.pdf Jan Tschichold at Penguin Books: A Resurgance [sic] of Classical Book Design]" (PDF).</ref>
Along with Gill Sans, Tschichold made use of Monotype [[Bembo]], Monotype [[Centaur (typeface)|Centaur]] (by [[Bruce Rogers (typographer)|Bruce Rogers]]) and Gill's [[Perpetua (typeface)|Perpetua]] typeface.<ref name="doubleday" />
The covers conformed to the golden ratio (4⅜" × 7⅛", 111mm × 181mm). For Penguin's distinctive orange color, Tschichold replaced it with a warmer tone.<ref name="doubleday" />
==Books on the topic== * ''Jan Tschichold: Typographer'', [[Ruari McLean]], [[David R. Godine, Publisher]], 1975. * ''Jan Tschichold: Master Typographer'', Cees W. De Jong, Thames & Hudson, 2008. * ''Penguin by Design: A Cover Story'', Phil Baines, Penguin, 2005. * ''Jan Tschichold, Designer: The Penguin Years'', Richard B. Doubleday, Oak Knoll Press, 2006.
Doubleday's book was met with severe criticism by Phil Baines in a review published by ''[[Eye (magazine)|Eye]]'' magazine.<ref>http://www.eyemagazine.com/review.php?id=134&rid=677</ref> ''Eye'' also published Doubleday's response.<ref>http://www.eyemagazine.com/opinion/article/tschichold-review-revisited</ref>
==See also== * ''Inspiring Penguins'', An online illustrated essay discussing Tschichold's work with Penguin [http://retinart.net/graphic-design/jan-tschicholds-inspiring-penguins/] * ''Jan Tschichold: Penguins, paperbacks and posters'', a Guardian slideshow of Tschichold and Penguin [https://www.theguardian.com/culture/gallery/2008/dec/05/design] * ''The Jan Tschichold Justification'' at Type Code [http://blog.typeslashcode.com/2010/05/12/the-jan-tschichold-justification/] * History of Penguin design, online at London's [[Design Museum]] [https://web.archive.org/web/20120225083733/http://designmuseum.org/design/penguin-books] * [[Style guide]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://archive.org/details/rulesforcomposi01presgoog ''Rules for Compositors and Readers at the University Press, Oxford''], by Oxford University Press at [https://archive.org/ Internet Archive] * [https://archive.org/details/authorsprintersd00collrich ''Authors' and Printers' Dictionary''], by F. Howard Collins at [https://archive.org/ Internet Archive]
[[Category:Graphic design]] [[Category:Communication design]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät | image = Provinssirock 20130616 - Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät - 01.jpg | caption = The band performing at [[Provinssirock]] in 2013 | alt = All four members performing on a stage. | image_size = | landscape = Yes | background = group_or_band | alias= PKN | origin = [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] | genre = [[Punk rock]] | years_active = {{Start date|2009}}–2016 | label = [[Red Lounge Records]], [[Sony Music]] | website = {{ConditionalURL}} | current_members = Pertti Kurikka
Kari Aalto
Sami Helle
Toni Välitalo }} '''Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät''' ('''PKN''', {{Langnf||Finnish|"Pertti Kurikka's [[name day]]s"}}) were a [[Finland|Finnish]] [[punk rock]] band, formed in 2009 in a charity workshop for adults with [[developmental disabilities]]. They are the main focus of the Finnish documentary film ''[[The Punk Syndrome]]''. In 2015, they qualified for the finals of [[Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu 2015|Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu]], which they later won; they represented Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest 2015 but got knocked out in the semi-final. The band disbanded in December 2016 when guitarist Pertti Kurikka turned 60 years old and retired from playing punk rock.{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/art-2000005022200.html|title=Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivien viimeisellä keikalla Tapaninpäivänä oli hikistä, ahdasta ja tunteikasta eli aivan mahtavaa|date=27 December 2016|publisher=|accessdate=5 October 2017|language=fi}} ==History== ===Formation (2004-2012)=== Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät began in a workshop run by Lyhty, a charity for adults with developmental disabilities. In 2004, Pertti Kurikka, the future guitarist of the band, met organizer Kalle Pajamaa of Lyhty.{{cite web| title = Never mind the mall punks, here’s Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät!| author = Arttu Tolonen| work =Finnish Music Quarterly |date=June 2013| accessdate = 6 March 2015| url = http://www.fmq.fi/2013/06/never-mind-the-mall-punks-heres-pertti-kurikan-nimipaivat/}} Pajamaa, who remains manager of the band today, noticed Kurikka's potential and sought to establish a band based upon him.{{cite web| title = Nytpedia: Tällainen yhtye on Pertti Kurikan nimipäivät|trans-title=Nytpedia: This is what the band Pertti Kurikan nimipäivät is like| work =Nyt| date = 2 March 2015| accessdate = 6 March 2015| url = http://nyt.fi/a1305932608636| language = Finnish}} They worked on the band's formation over the next five years, and in 2009 the band made its debut. In 2009, Finnish director [[Pekka Karjalainen]] sought music performed by people with disabilities for the film ''[[Vähän kunnioitusta]]'',{{cite web| title = The Story of PKN, the Finnish punk sensation ready to rock Eurovision| work = Nyt| date = 3 March 2015| accessdate = 6 March 2015| url = http://nyt.fi/a1305933792584}} which tells the story of a young girl with a [[learning disability]] aspiring to live an independent and normal life. Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät is featured in the film with their first-ever [[Demo (music)|demo]]: "Kallioon!".{{cite web| title = Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät osallistuu Uuden Musiikin Kilpailuun| author = Arto Mäenpää| work =KaaosZine| date = 13 January 2015| accessdate = 6 March 2015| url = http://kaaoszine.fi/pertti-kurikan-nimipaivat-osallistuu-uuden-musiikin-kilpailuun/|trans-title=Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät takes part in Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu|language=Finnish}} The song became a hit, and the band soon discovered that they had a following outside the circle of disabled people. In 2012, their fame grew as they were the main subject of ''[[The Punk Syndrome]]'', a Finnish documentary film. The documentary, depicting the band's story from its outset to their first European tour, earned them a following in Scandinavia and Germany.{{cite web|last1=Hay|first1=Mark|title=A Finnish Punk Band with Learning Disabilities Is Going to Eurovision|url=https://www.vice.com/read/a-finnish-punk-band-with-learning-disabilities-is-going-to-eurovision-189|website=VICE|accessdate=4 March 2015|date=3 March 2015}} ===2014: Charity concert with Mr. Lordi=== In 2014, the band performed in a charity concert with [[Mr. Lordi]] of the Finnish rock band, [[Lordi]]. The charity concert was held in Rovaniemi on 23 May 2014 for benefit of the mentally-disabled community of [[Mozambique]] and the Lapland Metkat Association.{{cite web|url=http://www.kvtl.fi/fi/ajankohtaista/lisaa-ajankohtaisia/?nid=1173 |title=Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät point Mr. Lordi May Rovaniemi|publisher=Kvtl.fi |date=2014-02-28 |accessdate=2015-02-18 |language=fi}} Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät's bold and unusual take on Eurovision has been compared to that of Lordi, [[Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest 2006|Finland's 2006 Eurovision entry]] and the winner of [[Eurovision Song Contest 2006|that year's contest]].{{cite web| title = The Punk Syndrome: Band With Down Syndrome Applies for Eurovision| work = [[Sputnik (news agency)|Sputnik]]| date = 21 January 2015| accessdate = 6 March 2015| url = http://sputniknews.com/society/20150119/1017088930.html}} ===2015: Eurovision Song Contest 2015=== The band entered [[Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu]], Finland's national selection for [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015]] with the song "[[Aina mun pitää]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1zcie_ykFqo|title=UMK15 // PERTTI KURIKAN NIMIPÄIVÄT: "Aina mun pitää"|publisher=Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu on Youtube. |date=2015-01-13 |accessdate=2015-02-18 |language=fi}} They entered the contest in order to raise awareness for people with Down's Syndrome.{{cite web|url=http://www.deathandtaxesmag.com/235838/punk-band-with-down-syndrome-looks-to-raise-awareness-in-eurovision-song-contest/ |title=Punk band with Down Syndrome looks to raise awareness in Eurovision Song Contest|publisher=deathandtaxes.com. |date=2015-02-02 |accessdate=2015-02-18}} On 7 February 2015, the band was one of the three acts from the first-semi finals to advance to the finals.{{cite web|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2015/02/07/umk-2015-satin-circus-advance-to-the-final/77617/|title=UMK 2015: SATIN CIRCUS, PERTTI KURIKAN NIMIPÄIVÄT AND NORLAN EL MISIONARIO ADVANCE TO THE FINAL|publisher=wiwibloggs.com. |date=2015-02-07 |accessdate=2015-02-18}} On 28 February 2015, the band won Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu 2015, thereby becoming [[Finland in the Eurovision Song Contest|Finland's representative]] for the Eurovision Song Contest in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] in May 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=pertti_kurikan_nimipaeivaet_win_umk_in_finland|title=Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät win UMK in Finland!|publisher=eurovision.tv. |date=2015-02-28 |accessdate=2015-02-28}} PKN was the first punk band to compete in Eurovision. PKN's Eurovision bid was noticed by the international media and covered, for instance, by the BBC,{{cite web|title=Finland punk band PKN set for Eurovision|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-31682196|website=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=4 March 2015}}{{cite web|title=Finnish punk band with a difference|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p02l4jrc|website=BBC World Service|publisher=BBC|accessdate=4 March 2015|date=2 March 2015}} ''The Guardian'',{{cite web|last1=Crouch|first1=David|title=Finnish punk band with a difference take a punt at Eurovision title|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/feb/27/finnish-punk-band-take-punt-eurovision-title|website=The Guardian|accessdate=4 March 2015|date=27 February 2015}} VICE and the Associated Press.{{cite web|title=Disabled punk rockers to compete in Eurovision Song Contest|url=https://www.yahoo.com/music/s/disabled-punk-rockers-compete-eurovision-song-contest-165229024.html|website=Yahoo! Music|accessdate=4 March 2015|date=1 March 2015}} [[Posti Group|Posti]] issued a PKN stamp on 11 May 2015, eight days before the first Eurovision semi-final in Vienna.{{cite web|title=Let's cheer on Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät to Eurovision victory|url=http://posti.fi/english/current/2015/20150428_perttikurikannimipaivat.html|publisher=Posti|accessdate=29 April 2015|date=28 April 2015}} ==Members== The band has four members: guitarist Pertti Kurikka, vocalist Kari Aalto, bassist Sami Helle and Toni Välitalo on drums. ===Pertti Kurikka=== Pertti Kurikka (born 26. December 1956 in [[Vihti]]){{cite web| title = Suomen euroviisuedustaja Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät pitää pissatauot ajallaan | author = Jouni K. Kemppainen| work = Kuukausiliite| publisher = ''[[Helsingin Sanomat]]''| date = 13 February 2015| accessdate = 16 March 2015 | url = http://www.hs.fi/kuukausiliite/a1305926871073| language = fi}} is the band's guitarist. He writes the music for the band and also some of the lyrics.{{cite web|url=http://kovasikajuttu.fi/en/topics/band-members |accessdate=March 7, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402123827/http://kovasikajuttu.fi/en/topics/band-members |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |title=Pertti Kurikka (guitar)}} He has released a spoken word cassette{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Kalevi-Helvetti-Kertoo-kummitusjuttuja/release/3369541 |title=Kalevi Helvetti - Kertoo Kummitusjuttuja (Cassette, Album) at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25}} and a book{{cite web|author= |url=http://nyt.fi/a1305862570326 |title="Musta haamu tappaa" – Pertti Kurikan synkkä sivupersoona Kalevi Helvetti julkaisi kirjan - Kirjat - Nyt |publisher=Nyt.fi |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25 |language=fi}} of horror stories under the pseudonym Kalevi Helvetti. He also edits a [[zine]] called "Kotipäivä" ("Home Day").{{cite web| title = Suomen euroviisuedustajat henkilökuvissa | author = [[Rakel Liekki|Tiina-Rakel Liekki]]| work = Kioski| publisher = ''[[Yle]]''| date = 14 May 2015| accessdate = 17 May 2015 | url = http://erikoiset.kioski.yle.fi/jutut/1505-pkn/| language = fi}} Kurikka has been listening to punk for 30 years, but also listens to many other music genres ranging from classical to schlager and disco to children's music.{{cite web|url=http://www.kodinkuvalehti.fi/artikkeli/hyva_mieli/ihmissuhteet/pertti_kurikka_hei_vahan_kunnioitusta |title=Pertti Kurikka: "Idea Euroviisuihin osallistumisesta oli minun" | Kodin Kuvalehti |publisher=Kodinkuvalehti.fi |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25|language=fi}} He visits church regularly and plans to retire and stop playing music when he turns 60. He can also play the [[street organ]]. ===Kari Aalto=== Kari Aalto (born 25. May 1976 in [[Tampere]]){{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/a1432431999816?ref=hs-top4-3 |title=PKN:n punkkarit saivat kotimatkalla kuninkaallisen kohtelun: Ykkösluokka, kapteenin tervehdys, lahja henkilökunnalta - Euroviisut - Kulttuuri - Helsingin Sanomat |publisher=Hs.fi |date=2015-05-24 |accessdate=2015-08-25 |language=fi}} is the singer of the band and also writes most of their lyrics. He is a school friend of Kurikka.{{cite web|url=http://www.iltasanomat.fi/musiikki/art-1421987563526.html|title=Viisusuosikki Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät -tähtien koskettavat elämäntarinat: "Äitiä oli aina ikävä"|author=Maiju Majamaa|work=Ilta-Sanomat |language=fi}} He has his own talk show on Finnish local radio station Bassoradio.{{cite web|url=http://www2.ray.fi/fi/ray/ajankohtaista/euroviisupunkkari-kari-aalto-is%C3%A4nn%C3%B6i-taas-basson-ohjelmaa|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403001303/http://www2.ray.fi/fi/ray/ajankohtaista/euroviisupunkkari-kari-aalto-is%C3%A4nn%C3%B6i-taas-basson-ohjelmaa|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2015-04-03|title=Euroviisupunkkari Kari Aalto isännöi taas Basson ohjelmaa | ray.fi|publisher=|date=|accessdate=2015-08-25|language=fi}} He can play drums, bass and keyboards. He loves motorcycles, American cars, women and alcohol.{{cite web|url=http://www.iltasanomat.fi/viihde/art-1425705934758.html|title=PKN-laulaja Kari Aalto kertoo nolosta kokemuksesta Ray:n lehdessä – sai ravintolaan porttikiellon|author=Siina Leppä|work=Ilta-Sanomat |language=fi}}{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/aihe/yle_stage/75302|title=YLE|work=yle.fi|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221042750/http://yle.fi/aihe/yle_stage/75302|archivedate=2015-02-21|df=}} He listens to 1950s and 1960s rock, psychobilly, rockabilly, surf, doowop and also rap, heavy metal and folk.{{cite web|author=Noora Jussila |url=http://www.vihrealanka.fi/henkil%C3%B6t/onnen-p%C3%A4iv%C3%A4t |title=Onnen päivät | Vihreä Lanka |publisher=Vihrealanka.fi |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25|language=fi}} He does not listen to punk in his spare time, as nowadays it is his profession. ===Sami Helle=== Sami Helle (born 1973){{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hs.fi/kuukausiliite/a1305926871073 |title=Suomen euroviisuedustaja Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät pitää pissatauot ajallaan - Euroviisut - Kuukausiliite - Helsingin Sanomat |publisher=Hs.fi |date=2015-02-13 |accessdate=2015-08-25 |language=fi}}{{cite web|author=Maiju Majamaa |url=http://www.iltasanomat.fi/musiikki/art-1421987563526.html |title=Viisusuosikki Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät -tähtien koskettavat elämäntarinat: "Äitiä oli aina ikävä" - Musiikki - Ilta-Sanomat |publisher=Iltasanomat.fi |date=2015-01-24 |accessdate=2015-08-25}} plays bass in the band and also sings background vocals. As a child he lived in [[Boston]], [[New York City]], [[Paris]] and [[Antibes]], so he can speak fluent English. He is politically active as a member of the Finnish [[Centre Party (Finland)|Central Party]]{{cite web|author=Hilkka Säävälä |url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/keskusta_uhoaa_voittavansa_jo_euroviisutkin/7826248 |title=Keskusta uhoaa voittavansa jo euroviisutkin | Yle Uutiset |publisher=yle.fi |date=2015-02-24 |accessdate=2015-08-25}} and also as activist of ''Me itse'', an organization of disabled people.{{cite web|url=http://www.kvtl.fi/fi/me-itse/ajankohtaista/kasikynkka-projekti/puhujapankki/kokemuspuhujat-aakkosjarjestyksessa/sami-helle/|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150311095343/http://www.kvtl.fi/fi/me-itse/ajankohtaista/kasikynkka-projekti/puhujapankki/kokemuspuhujat-aakkosjarjestyksessa/sami-helle/|deadurl=yes|title=Sami Helle - Kehitysvammaisten tukiliitto ry|date=11 March 2015|archivedate=11 March 2015|publisher=|accessdate=5 October 2017 |language=fi}} He wishes to become a municipal councillor of Helsinki and later a member of the parliament.{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/ylex/uutiset/pkn-basisti_sami_helle_eduskuntaan_paasy_on_mun_haave/3-7844757 |title=YleX |publisher=yle.fi |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25 |language=fi}} ===Toni Välitalo=== Toni Välitalo (born 1982 or 1983) is the drummer and also the youngest member of the band.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/a1425179182318 |title=Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät HSTV:n haastattelussa: "Tuli tunne, että nyt tulee Surun pyyhin silmistäni" - Euroviisut - Kulttuuri - Helsingin Sanomat |publisher=Hs.fi |date= |accessdate=2015-08-25}} He started playing drums at the age of six.{{cite web|author=Kirsikka Kiviniemi |url=http://www.iltasanomat.fi/euroviisut/art-1425344863581.html |title=PKN-viisurumpalin isä: Tällainen Toni oli lapsena - Euroviisut - Ilta-Sanomat |publisher=Iltasanomat.fi |date=2015-03-03 |accessdate=2015-08-25 |language=fi}} In addition to punk, he plays other genres such as [[jenkka]], blues and [[mazurka]]. His favourite music is [[Schlager music#Finland|Finnish schlager]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/a1423199307743 |title=UMK-kilpailijat valmistautuvat iltaan: yksi takoo Katri Helenaa, toinen etsii kadonnutta ääntä - Euroviisut - Kulttuuri - Helsingin Sanomat |publisher=Hs.fi |date=2015-01-14 |accessdate=2015-08-25}} ===Kalle Pajamaa=== Disability director Kalle Pajamaa (born 1979) is the band's concert manager and arranges the songs for the band. He is affectionately called the fifth member of the band.{{cite web| title = Nimipäiväjuhlien järjestäjä| author = | work = [[Kouvolan Sanomat]]| date = 5 January 2013| accessdate = 16 March 2015| url = http://www.kouvolansanomat.fi/Takahuone/2013/01/05/Nimipäiväjuhlien_järjestäjä/201314/480| language = fi}} ==Discography== ===Compilation albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Details ! scope="col"| Peak chart positions |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em;font-size:85%;"| [[The Official Finnish Charts|FIN]]
{{cite web|url=http://finnishcharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Pertti+Kurikan+Nimip%E4iv%E4t|title=Discography Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät|publisher=Finnish Charts Portal. Hung Medien (Steffen Hung)|last=Hung|first=Steffen}} |- ! scope="row"| ''[[Kuus kuppia kahvia ja yks kokis]]'' | * Released: 7 December 2012 * Label: Airiston Punk-levyt * Format: [[Music download|Digital download]], [[Compact Disc|CD]] | 17 |- ! scope="row"| ''Sikakovapaketti'' | * Released: 2012 * Label: N/A * Format: Digital download, CD | — |- ! scope="row"| ''Coffee Not Tea'' | * Released: 2013 * Label: Constant Flux * Format: Digital download, CD | — |- ! scope="row"| ''The Best of Greatest Hits'' | * Released: 8 May 2015 * Label: [[Epic Records]] * Format: Digital download, CD | 4 |- | colspan="20" style="font-size:85%"| "—" denotes an album that did not chart or was not released in that territory. |} ===Extended plays=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col"| Title ! scope="col"| Details |- ! scope="row"| ''Ei yhteiskunta yhtä miestä kaipaa'' | * Released: October 2010 * Label: Airiston Punk-Levyt, Red Lounge Records * Format: Digital download, CD |- ! scope="row"| ''Päättäjä on pettäjä'' | * Released: June 2011 * Label: Headbands * Format: Digital download, CD |- ! scope="row"| ''Osaa eläimetkin pieree'' | * Released: November 2011 * Label: Mauski Records, Punk & Pillu * Format: Digital download, CD |- ! scope="row"| ''Asuntolaelämää'' | * Released: October 2012 * Label: Airiston Punk-levyt * Format: Digital download, CD |- ! scope="row"| ''Jarmo'' | * Released: 20 November 2013 * Label: Airiston Punk-Levyt, Punk & Pillu * Format: Digital download, CD |- ! scope="row"| ''Mies haisee / Joe Weider'' | * Released: February 2015 * Label: Mauski Records, Punk & Pillu * Format: Digital download, CD |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col"| Title ! scope="col"| Year ! scope="col"| Album |- ! scope="row"| "Mongoloidi" | rowspan="2"| 2014 | rowspan="5" {{n/a|''Non-album singles''}} |- ! scope="row"| "Me ollaan runkkareita" |- ! scope="row"| "[[Aina mun pitää]]" | rowspan="3"| 2015 |- ! scope="row"| "Mies haisee" |- ! scope="row"| "Oma rauha" |} ==References== {{Portal|Finland|Punk rock|Disability|Eurovision}} {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{commons}} *{{Official website}} *[http://yle.fi/aihe/umk2015/pertti-kurikan-nimipaivat Pertti Kurikan Nimipäivät Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu 2015 page] {{fi icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20150301032926/http://yle.fi/uutiset/watch_pkn_bringing_punk_hope_to_new_music_competition_finals/7835130 English article about the band in Finnish Broadcast Company's news page] *{{Discogs artist|2018297}} {{S-start}} {{s-ach}} {{Succession box| | before=[[Softengine]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Piotr Fedorovich Nazarov | image = Nazarov-Piotr-Fedorovich-28 smw.jpg | imagesize = 200px | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 25 December 1921 | birth_place = [[Kochkovsky District|Kochki]], [[Novosibirsk Oblast]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]] | death_date = 19 April 1988 | death_place = [[Leningrad]], [[USSR]] | field = [[Painting]] | citizenship = [[USSR]] | nationality = [[Russians|Russian]] | training = [[Repin Institute of Arts]] | movement = [[Realism (visual art)|Realism]] | works = | patrons = }}
'''Piotr Fedorovich Nazarov''' ({{lang-ru|Пё́тр Фё́дорович Наза́ров}}; 25 December 1921 in [[Kochkovsky District|Kochki]], [[Novosibirsk Oblast]], Soviet Russia – 19 April 1988 in Leningrad, USSR) was a Soviet and Russian painter and Art teacher, who lived and worked in Leningrad city, and who is regarded as one of representatives of the [[Leningrad School of Painting|Leningrad school of painting]].<ref>''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.''- Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. – pp.365, 390, 393, 394, 396-398, 402, 403, 405.</ref>
== Biography == '''Piotr Fedorovich Nazarov''' was born on 25 December 1921 in the village of [[Kochkovsky District|Kochki]], [[Novosibirsk Oblast]], Soviet Russia.<ref name="Sergei Ivanov 2007. p.365">Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.''- Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. – p.365.</ref>
In 1931 Nazarov's family moved to Krasnoyarsk city, Eastern Siberia. Here he spent his childhood and teenage years. This time impressions influenced in the future on the formation of the young artist and choose the theme for some his paintings.
In autumn 1940, Nazarov was drafted into the [[Red Army]]. He was a veteran of World War II, participated in the [[Great Patriotic War]], he fought in the infantry in units of the 5th Army.
After demobilization in 1946, Nazarov came to [[Leningrad]] and entered at Tavricheskaya Art School, where he graduated in 1950.
In the same year, Nazarov joined the first course of painting department of the [[Repin Institute of Arts|Leningrad Institute of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture named after Ilya Repin]]. He studied of Piotr Belousov, Mikhail Platunov, Valery Pimenov.<ref name="Sergei Ivanov 2007. p.365"/>
In 1956 Nazarov graduated from [[Repin Institute of Arts|Leningrad Institute of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture namen after Ilya Repin]] in [[Rudolf Frentz]] personal Art Studio. His graduation work was a historical painting named "Lenin at the opening of the first power plant in rural Kashino", dedicated to the first steps to implement the plan of industrialization of Soviet Russia ([[GOELRO plan]]).<ref>''Anniversary Directory graduates of Saint Petersburg State Academic Institute of Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture named after Ilya Repin, Russian Academy of Arts. 1915 - 2005''. - Saint Petersburg: Pervotsvet Publishing House, 2007. p.76.</ref>
In the years 1957-1970, Nazarov worked as an artist in various organizations in Leningrad, and he also painted to order. Starting in 1957, Nazarov participated in Art Exhibitions. He painted genre and historical paintings, portraits, landscapes, still lifes, sketches from the life. His personal exhibition was in [[Leningrad]] in 1981.
For the manner of Nazarov the characteristic variety of techniques, decorative, skilful of plein air painting. The coloring of his work is saturated, painting is based on the relationship of warm and cold tones, and light and shadow contrasts.
Nazarov was a member of the [[Leningrad Union of Artists]] since 1970.<ref>''Directory of members of the Leningrad branch of Union of Artists of Russian Federation''. - Leningrad: Khudozhnik RSFSR, 1987. - p.89.</ref> In years 1970-1988, Nazarov worked as Art Teacher in the Vera Mukhina Art Institute in Leningrad.<ref name="Sergei Ivanov 2007. p.365"/>
Piotr Fedorovich Nazarov died on 19 April 1988 in [[Leningrad]] aged sixty-seven. His paintings reside in art museums and private collections in Russia, England, in the U.S., Japan, and other countries.
==See also== * [[Leningrad School of Painting]] * [[List of Russian artists]] * [[List of 20th-century Russian painters]] * [[List of painters of Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]] * [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== Bibliography == * ''Exhibition of works by Leningrad artists of 1960. Exhibition catalogue.'' - Leningrad: Khudozhnik RSFSR, 1963. -p. 13. * ''Autumn Exhibition of works by Leningrad artists of 1962. Exhibition Catalogue''. - Leningrad: : Khudozhnik RSFSR, 1962. - p. 19. * ''The Leningrad Fine Arts Exhibition''. - Leningrad: Khudozhnik RSFSR, 1964. - p. 35. * ''Directory of members of the Leningrad branch of Union of Artists of Russian Federation''. - Leningrad: Khudozhnik RSFSR, 1987. - p. 89. * ''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.'' - Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. – pp. 365, 390, 393, 394, 396-398, 402, 403, 405. {{ISBN|5-901724-21-6}}, {{ISBN|978-5-901724-21-7}}. * ''Anniversary Directory graduates of Saint Petersburg State Academic Institute of Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture named after Ilya Repin, Russian Academy of Arts. 1915 - 2005''. - Saint Petersburg: Pervotsvet Publishing House, 2007. P.76.

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Essay|date=June 2010}} }}
The '''Sheffield Repertory Theatre''' was a [[theatre company]] in [[Sheffield]], [[South Yorkshire]], [[England]].
Herbert Prince, a railway clerk, founded the amateur dramatics society in 1919,<ref name="Long">Frank Long "Sheffield" in Colin Chambers ''Twentieth Century Theatre'', London: Continuum, 2002, p.687</ref> a first meeting is recorded at the Oxford Street Settlement in Shipton Street that year, which became the Sheffield Repertory Theatre in 1923. A meeting in October 1923 formed an Executive Committee for a professional Company, consisting of Wilfred Vickers, W.C. Landon, C.V. McNally, A. Ballard, H.W. d. Harkcom and [[Herbert M. Prentice]]. The subscription was 3 [[shilling]]s and [[Sixpence (British coin)|sixpence]].
At the first Annual Meeting in January 1924, the aims were formulated: #To promote and encourage interest in the Drama and kindred Arts. #To produce Plays #To arrange lectures, recitals, play-readings and discussions #To promote social intercourse amongst the members #To form a library of dramatuc literature for the use of members #The establishment of a permanent Repertory Theatre in Sheffield
Their first performances took place at the Little Theatre in Shipton Street. Later the Company hired the South Street Schoolroom in Eldon Street. In 1928 the Company gained a permanent venue,<ref name="Long"/> and moved to the former Temperance Hall, in Townhead Street. The seating of this new Repertory Theatre was 319 in the saloon (Stalls) and 222 in the Balcony.
With the outbreak of war in 1939, the theatre was closed, along with nearly all British theatres by a government fearful of German bombing and consequent mass loss of life in such public buildings. This closure led to a most bizarre period. In order to resolve the financial crisis the Company arranged to reform in Southport, a de-restricted area, and carry on the business there. Despite the government allowing the theatre in Sheffield to re-open by 1940, a binding contract had already been signed in Southport. It thus proved impractical to operate in both towns and the decision was taken that the Company should remain in Southport. Over 240 productions took place in the [[Lancashire]] resort by a Yorkshire repertory during the war. The building in Townhead Street was eventually hired out for storage.
At the end of the war, the Company was able to return to its natural home, although it owed a debt to Southport for its survival. The theatre was in a dishevelled condition, following its utilitarian usage during the war, but the Company, helped by willing volunteers successfully renovated the auditorium in 1945, allowing it to re-open to the theatre-going public, with the appropriately titled play, ''The Peaceful Inn''.
By 1951, the theatre was a cultural and financial success. Most patrons bought season tickets, and so would attend every new performance. Sheffield was one of the few regional theatres to adopt a fortnightly cycle of plays. This was generally accepted to provide a much higher quality of performance; most repertory changed weekly. Plays running the gamut from Shakespeare to interpretations of the latest 'West End Smash' would alternate throughout the year. The festive season saw not a '[[Pantomime|Panto]]' but a play designed to appeal to children, that would nonetheless cultivate their minds.
By 1953 the theatre was struggling to cope with its success. The building failed to meet increasing health and safety demands. The management took the decision to completely rebuild it. Stripped back to its bare walls, the interior was entirely renewed as a sleek 'Fifties' auditorium replaced the stippled decor of the out-dated theatre. The Company had become so successful in the ensuing eight years since the war, that £20,000 could be invested in the internal rebuild of the premises.
In March 1954, the theatre re-opened and its success continued unabated, under the leadership of Geoffrey Ost, who had been the director since 1938, a service broken only by his wartime call-up. In 1959 Ost was awarded an honorary Doctorate at the University (a Scholarship still exists under his name). The future acting stars who were members of the Company include [[Peter Sallis]], [[Patrick McGoohan]], [[Patrick Stewart]], [[Paul Eddington]], [[Keith Barron]] and Sir [[Nigel Hawthorne]]. Actors such as Sir [[Alec Guinness]] and [[Patrick Macnee]] also performed in individually contracted productions and Sir [[Donald Wolfit]] was an assistant stage manager there. However Sheffield Rep. was really all about the local community - it only survived and prospered because many local people gave their labour and support on a voluntary or semi-professional basis, although plenty of local paid work was also provided.
The company was identified as a significant repertory company in the UK by the [[Arts Council of Great Britain|Arts Council]] during the 1960s, and a trust was formed to oversee the construction of a new building.<ref name="Hartnoll">Phyllis Hartnoll (ed) ''The Oxford Companion to the Theatre'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1983, p.195</ref> The new [[Crucible Theatre]] replaced the old theatre in 1971 financed by the Arts Council, Sheffield City Council and public donations.<ref name="Hartnoll"/> Geoffrey Ost was still there, noted as 'General Advisor'.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Amateur theatre companies in England]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1923]] [[Category:Organizations disestablished in 1971]] [[Category:Theatres in Sheffield]]

{{About|1986 Telugu film|Telugu lyricist|Sirivennela Sitaramasastri}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Sirivennela | image = Sirivennela.jpg | caption = | director = [[K. Viswanath]] | producer =Ch. Ramakrishna Reddy
N. Bhaskara Reddy
Ujjuri Chinaveerraju | writer = K. Viswanath (story)
[[Sainath Thotapalli]] (dialogues)
[[Sirivennela Sitaramasastri]] (lyrics) | starring = [[Sarvadaman D. Banerjee|Sarvadaman Banerjee]]
[[Suhasini Mani Ratnam|Suhasini]]
[[Moon Moon Sen]]
[[Meena]]
[[S. K. Misro]] | music = [[K. V. Mahadevan]]
[[Hariprasad Chaurasia]] (flute renderings)
[[Sivamani]] (drums) | cinematography =[[M. V. Raghu]] | editing =G. G. Krishna Rao | released = {{film date|df=y|1986|5|20}} | runtime = 181 min. | language = Telugu | budget = }} '''''Sirivennela''''' is a 1986 [[Telugu film|Telugu]] [[romance film]], written and directed by [[K. Viswanath]]. The film won [[Nandi Award]]s for Best lyrics, Best Male Playback Singer, Best Cinematography and Best Supporting Actress. The film was screened at the [[Asia Pacific Film Festival]], the [[International Film Festival of India]], the [[Moscow Film Festival]] and the [[Annapurna International School of Film and Media|AISFM Film Festival]].[http://www.aisfm.edu.in/blog/2014/the-films-of-k-viswanath/ The films of K. Viswanath — AISFM Blog]{{cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/if-music-is-the-food-of-love-lyrics-are-the-soul/article2833387.ece | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | first=Suresh | last=Krishnamoorthy | title=If music is the food of love, lyrics are the soul | date=26 January 2012}} The film was shot in [[Jaipur]] and [[Kerala]]. The film had [[Hariprasad Chaurasia]]'s flute rendering and a cameo of drummer [[Sivamani]].[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0249964/locations Sirivennela (1986) - Filming Locations - IMDb] The film was dubbed in Tamil as ''Raaga Devathai''.https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=P9oYG7HA76QC&dat=19870724&printsec=frontpage&hl=en ==Plot== Hari Prasad ([[Sarvadaman Banerjee]]), a blind [[flutist]] lives along with his younger sister in a village near [[Jaipur]], which was also a tourist attraction. Though he lacks knowledge of classical music, he plays flute beautifully and makes a living by playing it to tourists. One day, guide Jyothirmai ([[Moon Moon Sen]]) comes there along with a bunch of tourists and listens to his flute. She understands his talent and helps him understand nature and to become a famous flutist. Years pass and Hari Prasad becomes Pandit Hari Prasad. Unknown to her, Hari Prasad admires her very much and dedicates all his albums to her. Meanwhile, a mute painter Subhashini ([[Suhasini]]) who meets him in his village, falls for him. Subhashini expresses her feelings through her paintings and gradually her brother understands her feelings regarding Hari Prasad. He approaches Hari Prasad's uncle with a marriage proposal. But at the same time Hari Prasad reveals his admiration for Jyothirmai. This shocks Jyothirmai as she previously worked as an escort to rich tourists. She tries to hint Hari Prasad about her not so decent past, but is overwhelmed by his pure love and disregard for her external characters. Though she herself admires him, she feels that she would taint him with her impure past. She tells Hari Prasad that she couldn't marry him as she already engaged to a doctor. Hari Prasad takes it well as he always wanted Jyothirmai to be happy. On the wedding day, Jyothirmai commits suicide and requests in her last note that her eyes should be donated to Hari Prasad. She also requests that her funeral procession should appear like a marriage procession and her death should be hidden from Hari Prasad. Everyone tries to act normal and sends her as they are sending a bride to her in-laws. Hari Prasad keeps calm all the time and at last goes to the graveyard to say his final goodbyes to Jyothirmai. He tells shocked Subhashini that it's impossible to hide the death of his angel from him. The film ends with Hari Prasad and Subhashini mourning silently in the graveyard. ==Cast== *[[Sarvadaman D. Banerjee|Sarvadaman Banerjee]] as Pandit Hari Prasad *[[Suhasini Maniratnam|Suhasini]] as Subhashini *[[Moon Moon Sen]] as Jyotirmayi *[[Meena (actress)|Meena]] as Baby Meena *[[Samyuktha (actress)|Samyuktha]] as Hari's sister *[[J. V. Ramana Murthi]] *[[S. K. Misro]] *[[Shubha (actress)|Shubha]] *[[Sakshi Ranga Rao]] *[[Subhalekha Sudhakar]] *[[Garikapati Varalakshmi|Varalakshmi]] *Eashwara Rao *[[Nithya Ravindran]] ==Music== ''Sirivennela'' abounds in classical music composed by [[K. V. Mahadevan]] with flute renditions by the renowned [[flautist]] [[Hariprasad Chaurasia]].listing-index.ebay.com/movies/Sirivennela.html The movie saw the debut of [[Sirivennela Sitaramasastri]] as a [[lyricist]], who wrote all of the songs. Because of "the wonderful songs," rich in meaning, he penned for the movie, Sitarama Sastry has taken the name Sirivennela. Each of the songs is remembered to this day. The song "Vidhata Thalapuna", sung by [[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]] and [[P. Susheela]], is about [[Om|Aum]], the most sacred syllable in Hinduism, from which the [[Vedas|Veda]] traditions originated. Other notable songs include "Adibhikshuvu Vadinedi Koredhi" and "Ee gali Ee Nela." {{Track listing | all_lyrics = [[Sirivennela Sitaramasastri]] | all_music = K. V. Mahadevan | headline = Songs | extra_column = Singer(s) | title1 = Adibhikshuvu Vadinedi Koredhi | extra1 = [[S. P. Balasubramanyam]] | title2 = Chandamama Raave | extra2 = B. Vasantha | title3 = Chinuku Chinuku | extra3 = S. P. Balasubramanyam | title4 = Ee Gali Ee Nela | extra4 = S. P. Balasubramanyam | title5 = Merise Taraladeroopam | extra5 = S. P. Balasubramanyam | title6 = Patallo | extra6 = Prakash Rao, [[P. Susheela]] | title7 = Prakruthi Kanthaku | extra7 = S. P. Balasubramanyam | title8 = Polimeradhatipothunna | extra8 = S. P. Balasubramanyam, B. Vasantha | title9 = Vidhata Thalapuna | extra9 = S. P. Balasubramanyam, P. Susheela }} ==Awards== {{awards table}} |- | rowspan="4"|1986 | [[Sirivennela Sitaramasastri]]
(for "Vidatha Talapuna") | [[Nandi Award for Best Lyricist]] | {{won}} |- | [[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]]
(for "Vidatha Talapuna") | [[Nandi Award for Best Male Playback Singer]] | {{won}} |- | [[Moon Moon Sen]] | [[Nandi Award for Best Supporting Actress]] | {{won}} |- | [[M. V. Raghu]]{{cite news| url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/06/09/stories/2003060900910400.htm | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=The saga of a lensman | date=9 June 2003}} | [[Nandi Award for Best Cinematographer]] | {{won}} |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0249964|title=Sirivennela}} {{Kasinathuni Viswanath}} [[Category:1986 films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:Telugu-language films]] [[Category:Films about the arts]] [[Category:Films about blind people in India]] [[Category:Films about disability]] [[Category:Films about deaf people]] [[Category:Disability in fiction]] [[Category:Films directed by K. Mahadevan]] [[Category:Indian romantic musical films]] [[Category:Indian romance films]] [[Category:Indian musical films]] [[Category:1980s Telugu-language films]] [[Category:Telugu-language films dubbed in Tamil]]

revision.text:
{{For|the ideology arguing that feminist social science should be practiced from the standpoint of women|Standpoint feminism}}
{{technical|date=October 2018}} '''Standpoint theory''' is a theory for analyzing [[inter-subjective]] [[discourse]]s. This body of work concerns the ways that authority is rooted in individuals' knowledge (their [[perspective (cognitive)|perspective]]s), and the power that such authority exerts.
Standpoint theory's most important concept is that an individual's own perspectives are shaped by his or her social and political experiences. Standpoints are multifaceted rather than essentializing: while Hispanic women may generally share some perspectives, particularly with regard to ethnicity or sex, they are not defined solely by their participation in these categories. The amalgamation of a person's many experienced dimensions form a standpoint—a [[point of view (philosophy)|point of view]]—through which that individual sees and understands the world.
Standpoint theorists emphasize the utility of a naturalistic''',''' or everyday experiential, concept of knowing (i.e., [[epistemology]]). One's standpoint (whether reflexively considered or not) shapes which concepts are intelligible, which claims are heard and understood by whom, which features of the world are perceptually salient, which reasons are understood to be relevant and forceful, and which conclusions credible.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sprague|first=Joey|title=The standpoint of art/criticism|url=http://web.ebscohost.com/ehost/detail?vid=3&hid=13&sid=e26ca1ca-8c19-4976-ad8a-7d7af38f55a0%40sessionmgr15&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZQ%3d%3d#db=aph&AN=66905263}}</ref>
Standpoint theory supports what feminist theorist [[Sandra Harding]] calls [[strong objectivity]], or the notion that the perspectives of [[marginalized]] and/or oppressed individuals can help to create more objective accounts of the world. Through the outsider-within phenomenon, these individuals are placed in a unique position to point to patterns of behavior that those immersed in the dominant group culture are unable to recognize.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Allen|first=Brenda J.|title=Feminist Standpoint Theory: a Black Woman's Review of Organizational Socialization|journal=Communication Studies|year=1996|volume=47|issue=4|pages=257–271|doi=10.1080/10510979609368482}}</ref> Standpoint theory gives voice to the marginalized groups by allowing them to challenge the status quo as the outsider within. The status quo representing the dominant white male position of privilege.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Buzzanell|first=Patrice M.|title=A Feminist Standpoint Analysis of Maternity and Maternity Leave for Women with Disabilities|journal=Women and Language|year=2003|volume=26|issue=2|pages=53–65}}</ref>
The predominant culture in which all groups exist is not experienced in the same way by all persons or groups. The views of those who belong to groups with more social power are validated more than those in marginalized groups. Those in marginalized groups must learn to be [[bicultural]], or to "pass" in the [[dominant culture]] to survive, even though that perspective is not their own.<ref name="DeFranciscoVictoria">DeFrancisco, Victoria P. ''Communicating Gender Diversity: A Critical Approach''. Thousand Oaks: Sage Publications, INC., 2007.</ref>
==History== The original inspirations for standpoint theory can be seen in the works of [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel]], a [[German idealism|German idealist]] philosopher, who studied the different standpoints between slaves and masters in 1807.<ref>Wood, J.T. (2008). Critical feminist theories. In L.A. Baxter & D.O. Braithwaite (Eds.), Engaging theories in interpersonal communication: Multiple perspectives (pp. 323-334). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage.</ref> He claimed that the master-slave relationship is about people's belonging positions, and the groups affect how people receive knowledge and power.<ref>{{cite book|last=Griffin|first=Em|title=A First Look at COMMUNICATION THEORY: Standpoint Theory|year=2009|publisher=McGraw-Hill Higher Education|pages=441–453}}</ref> [[Karl Marx]] also discussed how the position of a worker shapes his or her knowledge.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} From these two scholars' studies, Nancy Hartsock examined standpoint theory by using relations between men and women. She published "The Feminist Standpoint: Developing Ground for a Specifically Feminist Historical Materialism" in 1983. Hartsock used Hegel's ideas of masters and slaves and Marx's ideas of class and [[capitalism]] as an inspiration to look into matters of sex and gender.
Contemporary standpoint theory often focuses on the social positions such as gender, [[Race (classification of humans)|race]], class, [[culture]], and economic status.<ref>Wallance, R. A., and A. Wolf (1995). ''Contemporary Sociological Theory: Continuing the classical tradition''. Englewood Cliffs, NJ: Prentice Hall.</ref> Standpoint theory seeks to develop a particular [[feminist epistemology]], that values the experiences of women and minorities as a source for knowledge.<ref>McCann and Kim, ''Feminist Theory Reader: Local and global perspectives'', 2003.</ref>.
Prominent standpoint theorists include [[Dorothy E. Smith|Dorothy Smith]], [[Nancy Hartsock]], [[Donna Haraway]], [[Sandra Harding]], [[Alison Wylie]], Lynette Hunter and [[Patricia Hill Collins]].
==Key concepts== Generally, standpoint theory gives insight into specific circumstances only available to the members of a certain collective standpoint. According to Michael Ryan, "the idea of a collective standpoint does not imply an essential overarching characteristic but rather a sense of belonging to a group bounded by a shared experience."<ref>''Encyclopedia of Social Theory'', 789.</ref>. Kristina Rolin states that "the assumption of essentialism is that all women share the same socially grounded perspective in virtue of being women, the assumption of automatic epistemic privilege is that epistemic advantage accrues to the subordinate automatically, just in virtue of their occupying a particular social position."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rolin|first=Kristina|date=2009|title=Standpoint Theory as a Methodology for the Study of Power Relations|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/20618192|journal=Hypatia|volume=24|issue=4|pages=218–226}}</ref> According to this approach: * A standpoint is a place from which [[human beings]] view the [[world]]. * A standpoint influences how the people adopting it [[social construct|socially construct]] the world. * A standpoint is a mental position from which things are viewed. * A standpoint is a position from which objects or principles are viewed and according to which they are compared and judged. * The inequalities of different social groups create differences in their standpoints. * All standpoints are partial; so (for example) [[Standpoint feminism]] coexists with other standpoints.
==Applications==
Since standpoint theory focuses on marginalized populations, it is often applied within fields that focus on these populations. Standpoint has been referenced as a concept that should be acknowledged and understood in the [[Social Work]] field, especially when approaching and assisting clients.<ref>Swigonski, M. E. (1993). "Feminist Standpoint Theory and the Questions of Social Work Research". ''Affilia'', 8(2), 171–183.</ref> Many marginalized populations rely on the welfare system to survive. Unfortunately, those who structure the welfare system typically have never needed to utilize its services before. Standpoint theory has been presented as a method to improving the [[welfare]] system by recognizing suggestions made by those within the welfare system.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Edmonds-Cady | first1 = C | year = 2009 | title = Getting to the grassroots: Feminist standpoints within the welfare movement | url = | journal = Journal of Sociology and Social Welfare | volume = 36 | issue = 2| pages = 11–33 }}</ref> In Africa, standpoint theory has catalyzed a social movement where women are introduced to the radio in order to promote awareness of their experiences and hardships and to help these women heal and find closure.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gatua | first1 = M. W. | last2 = Patton | first2 = T. O. | last3 = Brown | first3 = M. R. | year = 2010 | title = Giving voice to invisible women: "FIRE" as model of a successful women's community radio in Africa | url = | journal = Howard Journal of Communications | volume = 21 | issue = 2| pages = 164–181 | doi=10.1080/10646171003727441}}</ref> Another example dealing with Africa is slavery and how slavery differed greatly depending on if one was the slave or the master. If there were any power relationships there could never be a single perspective. No viewpoint could ever be complete, and there is no limit to anyone's perspective.
Asante and Davis’s (1989) study of interracial encounters in the workplace found that because of different cultural perspectives, approaching organizational interactions with others with different beliefs, assumptions, and meanings often leads to miscommunication. Brenda Allen stated in her research that, "Organizational members' experiences, attitudes, and behaviors in the workplace are often influenced by race-ethnicity"<ref>Allen, B. J. (1995). "'Diversity' and organizational communication". ''Journal of Applied Communication Research'', 23, 145.</ref>
Paul Adler and John Jermier suggest that management scholars should be aware of their standpoints. They write that those studying management should "consciously choose [their] standpoints and take responsibility for the impact (or lack of impact) of [their] scholarship on the world"<ref>Adler, Paul, and John Jermier. 2005. "Developing a field with more soul: Standpoint theory and public policy research for management scholars". ''The Academy of Management Journal'' 48 (6): 942.</ref>.
Jermier argued that all parts of a research study- identifying the problem, theorizing research questions, gathering and analyzing data, drawing conclusions, and the knowledge produced are there to some extent because of the researcher’s standpoint. This caused him to question what standpoint to adopt in the management of scientists. To avoid falling into limitations of the status quo and certain standpoints, he said that "the view from below has greater potential to generate more complete and more objective knowledge claims." He continues to say that, “if our desire is to heal the world, we will learn more about how the root mechanisms of the world work and about how things can be changed by adopting the standpoints of those people and other parts of nature that most deeply suffer its wounds.”<ref>Jermier, J.M. 1998. "Critical perspectives on organizational control". ''Administrative Science Quarterly'', 43: 235–256.</ref>
==Feminist standpoint theory<!--Section may be linked from elsewhere (see [[MOS:HEAD]]: do not rename without fixing linking articles)-->== {{main|Standpoint feminism}} Feminist standpoint theorists make three principal claims: (1) Knowledge is socially situated. (2) Marginalized groups are socially situated in ways that make it more possible for them to be aware of things and ask questions than it is for the non-marginalized. (3) Research, particularly that focused on power relations, should begin with the lives of the marginalized.<ref name=Bowell>{{cite web|last1=Bowell|first1=T.|title=Feminist Standpoint Theory|url=http://www.iep.utm.edu/fem-stan/|website=Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy}}</ref>
Feminist standpoint theorists such as Dorothy Smith, Patricia Hill Collins, Nancy Hartsock, and Sandra Harding claimed that certain socio-political positions occupied by women (and by extension other groups who lack social and economic privilege) can become sites of epistemic privilege and thus productive starting points for enquiry into questions about not only those who are socially and politically marginalized, but also those who, by dint of social and political privilege, occupy the positions of oppressors. This claim was specifically generated by Sandra Harding and as such, "Starting off research from women's lives will generate less partial and distorted accounts not only of women's lives but also of men's lives and of the whole social order."<ref name="Griffin_b">Griffin, E. M. (2009). ''A first look at communication theory'' (7th edn). New York, NY: McGraw-Hill.</ref> This practice is also quite evident when women enter into professions that are considered to be male oriented. [[Londa Schiebinger]] states, "While women now study at prestigious universities at about the same rate as men, they are rarely invited to join the faculty at top universities...The sociologist [[Harriet Zuckerman]] has observed that 'the more prestigious the institution, the longer women wait to be promoted.' Men, generally speaking, face no such trade-off."<ref>{{cite book|last=Schiebinger|first=Londa|title=Has feminism changed science?|year=1999|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=United States of America|pages=33–53}}</ref>
Standpoint feminists have been concerned with these dualisms for two related reasons. First, dualisms usually imply a hierarchical relationship between the terms, elevating one and devaluing the other.<ref name=WestTurner>West, R., and H. L. Turner (2004). ''Communication Theory. Analysis and Application''.</ref> He also said that when we suggest that decisions should be made rationally, not emotionally, for example, we are showing that reason holds a higher value in our culture than does emotion. Also, related to this issue is the concern that these dualisms often become gendered in our culture. In this process, men are associated with one extreme and women with the other. In the case of reason and emotion, women are identified with emotion. Because our culture values emotion less than reason, women suffer from this association. Feminist critics are usually concerned with the fact that dualisms force false dichotomies (partition of a whole) onto women and men, failing to see that life is less either/or than both/and, as [[relational dialectics theory]] holds.
==Criticisms== Critics argue that standpoint theory, despite challenging essentialism, relies itself on essentialism, as it focuses on the dualism of subjectivity and objectivity.<ref name=WestTurner /> In regards to feminist standpoint theory: though it does dispel many false generalizations of women, it is argued that focus on social groups and social classes of women is still inherently essentialist. Generalizations across the entire female gender can be broken into smaller more specific groups pertaining to women's different social classes and cultures, but are still generalized as distinct groups, and thus marginalization still occurs. West and Turner stated that an author by the name of Catherine O'Leary (1997) argued that although standpoint theory has been helpful in reclaiming women's experiences as suitable research topics, it contains a problematic emphasis on the universality of this experience, at the expense of differences among women's experiences.<ref name=WestTurner />
Another main criticism of Harding and Wood's standpoint theory is the credibility of strong objectivity vs. subjectivity. Standpoint theorists argue that standpoints are relative and cannot be evaluated by any absolute criteria, but make the assumption that the oppressed are less biased or more impartial than the privileged.<ref name="Griffin_b" /> This leaves open the possibility of an overbalance of power, in which the oppressed group intentionally or unintentionally becomes the oppressor. Intentional overbalance of power, or revenge, can manifest as justification for extremism and militarism, which can sometimes be seen in more extreme forms of feminism.
While the beginnings of standpoint theory are based on the critical paradigm from a Marxist view of social class oppression, a feminist philosophy developed in the 1970s and 1980s and the main focus has been on the feministic side. Other groups, as of now, need to be included into the theory and a new emphasis needs to be made toward other marginalized or muted groups. These groups envelop minorities, culturally different and the disabled or those that have a disability. When Harding and Wood conceived Standpoint theory they did not understand, when they defined it as a feminist view, that there are different cultures existing in the same social group. Many researchers are unsure of the idea of it having essentialism, as essentialism refers to the practice of generalizing all groups as though they were, in essence, the same.” Early standpoint theorists sought to understand the way in which the gendered identity of knowers affected their epistemic resources and capacities”<ref name="Wylie" />{{rp|48}}. These other muted or marginalized groups have a more realistic approach to standpoint theory as they have different experiences than those that are in power and even within those muted groups differences defined by different cultures of people can have an altered standpoint. This view gives a basis that in part Standpoint Theory has a central principle of the inversion thesis and Joshua St. Pierre defined this as "the inversion thesis gives epistemic authority to those marginalized by systems of oppression insofar as these people are often better knowers than those who benefit from oppression. Put simply: social dispossession produces epistemic privilege."
Part of standpoint theory’s return to favor comes from a re-articulation of its methodology, aims, and limitations that directly answer the criticisms mentioned above.
Wylie has perhaps provided the most succinct articulation of second-wave standpoint theory. For her, a standpoint does not mark out a clearly defined territory such as “women” within which members have automatic privilege but is a rather a posture of epistemic engagement. Responding to the claim that the situated knowledge thesis reifies essentialism, Wylie thus argues that it is "an open (empirical) question whether such structures obtain in a given context, what form they take, and how they are internalized or embodied by individuals".<ref name="Wylie" />{{rp|62}} Identities are complex and cannot be reduced to simple binaries. Likewise, she argues that the criticism of automatic privilege is falters insofar as a standpoint is never given, but is achieved. (St. Pierre)<ref name="Wylie">Wylie, Alison. 2012. "Feminist Philosophy of Science: Standpoint Matters." Presidential Address delivered to the Pacific Division APA, in ''Proceedings and Addresses of the American Philosophical Association'', 86.2: 47–76.</ref>
==See also== * [[Co-cultural communication theory]] * [[Critical race theory]] * [[Cultural studies]] * [[Groupthink]] * [[Intersectionality]] * [[Muted group theory]] * [[Standpoint feminism]] * [[Spiral of silence]]

==Literature== * Ryan, Michael. "Standpoint Theory." ''Encyclopedia of Social Theory''. Ed. George Ritzer. Vol. 2. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Reference, 2005. 789. Gale Virtual Reference Library. Web. 12 November 2012. *{{cite journal|last1=Rouse|first1=Joseph|title=Standpoint Theories Reconsidered|journal=Hypatia|date=November 2009|volume=24|issue=4|pages=200–209|doi=10.1111/j.1527-2001.2009.01068.x}} *{{cite journal|last1=Harnois|first1=Catherine E.|title=Race, Gender, and the Black Women's Standpoint|journal=Sociological Forum|date=March 2010|volume=25|issue=1|pages=68–85|doi=10.1111/j.1573-7861.2009.01157.x}} *{{cite journal|last1=Rolin|first1=Kristina|title=Standpoint Theory as a Methodology for the Study of Power Relations|journal=Hypatia|date=November 2009|volume=24|issue=4|pages=218–226|doi=10.1111/j.1527-2001.2009.01070.x}}
