{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} [[File:Edward Elgar 1917.jpg|thumb|right|Edward Elgar]] [[Edward Elgar|Sir Edward Elgar]]'s '''Symphony No. 1 in A{{music|flat}} major, Op. 55''' is one of his two completed symphonies. The first performance was given by the [[The Hallé|Hallé Orchestra]] conducted by [[Hans Richter (conductor)|Hans Richter]] in Manchester, England, on 3 December 1908. It was widely known that Elgar had been planning a symphony for more than ten years, and the announcement that he had finally completed it aroused enormous interest. The critical reception was enthusiastic, and the public response unprecedented. The symphony achieved what ''[[The Musical Times]]'' described as "immediate and phenomenal success", with a hundred performances in Britain, continental Europe and America within just over a year of its première.
The symphony is regularly programmed by British orchestras, and features occasionally in concert programmes in North America and Europe. It is well represented on record, with recordings ranging from the composer's 1931 version with the [[London Symphony Orchestra]] to modern digital recordings, of which more than 20 have been issued since the mid-1980s.
==Composition and première== Nearly ten years before composing his first symphony, Elgar had been intrigued by the idea of writing a symphony to commemorate General [[Charles George Gordon]] rather as [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]]'s [[Symphony No. 3 (Beethoven)|Eroica]] was originally intended to celebrate [[Napoleon Bonaparte]].<ref name=reed96>Reed p. 96</ref> In 1899 he wrote to his friend [[August Jaeger]] (the "Nimrod" of the [[Enigma Variations]]), "Now as to Gordon: the thing possesses me, but I can't write it down yet."<ref name=reed96/> After he completed his oratorio ''[[The Kingdom (Elgar)|The Kingdom]]'' in 1906 Elgar had a brief fallow period. As he passed his 50th birthday he turned to his boyhood compositions which he reshaped into ''[[The Wand of Youth]]'' suites during the summer of 1907.<ref name=k53/> He began work on a symphony and when he went to Rome for the winter<ref>"Court Circular", ''The Times'', 6 November 1907, p. 12</ref> he continued work on it, finishing the first movement. After his return to England he worked on the rest of the symphony during the summer of 1908.<ref name=k53>Kennedy, p. 53</ref>
Elgar had abandoned the idea of a "Gordon" symphony, in favour of a wholly non-programmatic work. He had come to consider [[abstract music]] as the pinnacle of orchestral composition. In 1905 he gave a lecture on [[Johannes Brahms]]'s [[Symphony No. 3 (Brahms)|Symphony No. 3]], in which he said that when music was simply a description of something else it was carrying a large art somewhat further than he cared for. He thought music, as a simple art, was at its best when it was simple, without description, as in the case of the Brahms symphony.<ref>"Brahms's Third Symphony – Sir E. Elgar's Analysis, ''The Manchester Guardian'', 9 November 1905, p. 8</ref> The first page of the manuscript carries the title, "Symphony for Full Orchestra, Op. 55."<ref name=reed97>Reed, p. 97</ref> To the music critic [[Ernest Newman]] he wrote that the new symphony was nothing to do with Gordon, and to the composer [[Walford Davies]] he wrote, "There is no programme beyond a wide experience of human life with a great charity (love) and a massive hope in the future."<ref name=k53/>
[[File:HansRichter1876.png|thumb|left|175px|alt=black and white Victorian photograph of the head and shoulders of a bespectacled man with a large dark beard|[[Hans Richter (conductor)|Hans Richter]], the dedicatee, conducted the première of the symphony]] The symphony was dedicated "To Hans Richter, Mus. Doc. True Artist and true Friend."<ref name=reed97/> It was premiered on 3 December 1908 in the [[Free Trade Hall]] in Manchester, with Richter conducting the [[Hallé Orchestra]]. The London première followed four days later, at the [[Queen's Hall]], with the [[London Symphony Orchestra]] conducted by Richter.<ref name=k53/> At the first rehearsal for the London concert, Richter addressed the orchestra, "Gentlemen, let us now rehearse the greatest symphony of modern times, written by the greatest modern composer – ''and not only in this country''." [[William Henry Reed]], who played in the LSO at that concert, recalled, "Arriving at the ''Adagio'', [Richter] spoke almost with the sound of tears in his voice and said: 'Ah! this is a real Adagio – such an Adagio as Beethove' would 'ave writ'."<ref name=reed97/>
''[[The Musical Times]]'' wrote in 1909, "To state that Elgar's Symphony has achieved immediate and phenomenal success is the bare truth." Within weeks of the première the symphony was performed in New York under [[Walter Damrosch]], Vienna under [[Ferdinand Löwe]], St. Petersburg under [[Alexander Siloti]], and Leipzig under [[Artur Nikisch]]. There were performances in Chicago, [[Boston]], Toronto and 15 British towns and cities.<ref name=mt1209>The Musical Times, 1 February 1909, p. 102</ref> By February 1909 the [[New York Philharmonic Orchestra]] had given two more performances at [[Carnegie Hall]] and had taken the work to "some of the largest inland cities ... It is doubtful whether any symphonic work has aroused so great an interest since [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky|Tchaikowsky]]'s ''[[Symphony No. 6 (Tchaikovsky)|Pathétique]]''."<ref>"Opera in New York – Our Own Correspondent", ''The Observer'', 14 February 1909, p. 5</ref> In the same period the work was played six times in London, under the baton of Richter, the composer, and [[Henry Joseph Wood|Henry Wood]].<ref name=mt1209/> Within just over a year there were a hundred performances worldwide.<ref>Jack, Adrian. [http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio3/classical/elgar/notes/note_symph1.shtml "Edward Elgar, Symphony No 1".] BBC Radio 3. Retrieved 7 April 2010.</ref>
''The Musical Times'' printed a digest of press comments on the symphony. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' was quoted as saying, "[T]hematic beauty is abundant. It is exquisite in the adagio, and in the first and second allegros, the latter a kind of scherzo; when the rhythmic impulse, the power and the passion are at their extreme height, when the music becomes almost frenzied in its superb energy, the sense of sheer beauty is still strong." ''[[The Morning Post]]'', wrote, "This is a work for the future, and will stand as a legacy for coming generations; in it are the loftiness and nobility that indicate a masterpiece, though its full appreciation will only be from the most serious-minded; to-day we recognise it as a possession of which to be proud." ''[[The Evening Standard]] said, ''Here we have the true Elgar – strong, tender, simple, with a simplicity bred of inevitable expression. ... The composer has written a work of rare beauty, sensibility, and humanity, a work understandable of all."<ref>All extracts in this paragraph are from the digest in ''The Musical Times'', 1 January 1909, pp. 153–54</ref>
''The Musical Times'' refrained from quoting ''[[The Observer]]'', which was the only dissenting voice among the main newspapers. It complained that the work was derivative of [[Felix Mendelssohn]], [[Johannes Brahms]] and [[Richard Wagner]], and thought the theme of the slow movement "cheap ready-made material". It allowed, however, that "Elgar's orchestration is so magnificently modern that the dress disguises the skeleton."<ref>"Music: The Elgar Symphony", ''The Observer'', 13 December 1908, p. 9</ref> This adverse view was in contrast with the praise in ''[[The Times]]'': "[A] great work of art, which is lofty in conception and sincere in expression, and which must stand as a landmark in the development of the younger school of English music." In ''[[The Guardian|The Manchester Guardian]]'', [[Samuel Langford]] described the work as "sublime ... the work is the noblest ever penned for instruments by an English composer."<ref>Langford, Samuel, ''The Manchester Guardian'', 3 December 1908, p. 5; and 4 December 1908, p. 9.</ref>
''The Times'' noted the influence of Wagner and Brahms: "There are characteristic reminiscences of ''[[Parsifal (opera)|Parsifal]]''... and rhythmically the chief theme looks like an offspring of Brahms" but concluded "it is not only an original work, but one of the most original and most important that has been added to the stock of recent music."<ref>"The Queen's-Hall Orchestra", ''The Times'', 2 January 1909, p. 11</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'', which also detected the influence of ''Parsifal'', and, in the finale, of [[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]'s ''[[Aida]]'', called the symphony "a work of such importance that conductors will not lightly let it drop."<ref>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1909/01/04/101860511.pdf "Elgar's Symphony – First Time Here".] ''The New York Times'', 4 January 1909, p. 9</ref>
==Musical analysis== The work is the only frequently-performed symphony whose main key is [[A-flat major]]. It is scored for three [[Western concert flute|flute]]s (one doubling [[piccolo]]), two [[oboe]]s and [[English horn|cor anglais]], two [[clarinet]]s and [[bass clarinet]], two [[bassoon]]s and [[contrabassoon]], four [[French horn|horn]]s, three [[trumpet]]s, three [[trombone]]s, [[tuba]], [[timpani]], percussion (including [[snare drum]], [[bass drum]] and [[cymbal]]s), two [[pedal harp|harp]]s, and [[string instrument|string]]s. It is in four movements: {{ordered list|list_style_type=upper-roman |''Andante. Nobilmente e semplice — Allegro'' |''Allegro molto'' |''Adagio'' |''Lento — Allegro'' }} [[File:Elgar1opening.jpg|thumb|450px|right|The opening and recurring theme]]The symphony is in a [[cyclic form]]: the incomplete "nobilmente" theme from the first movement returns in the finale for a complete ''grandioso'' statement after various transformations throughout the work. Elgar wrote, "the opening theme is intended to be simple &, in intention, noble & elevating ... the sort of ideal call – in the sense of persuasion, not coercion or command – & something above every day & sordid things."<ref>Elgar, Edward. Letter to Ernest Newman, 4 November 1908, reproduced in ''Edward Elgar: Letters of a Lifetime'', ed. Jerrold Northrop Moore (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1990), p. 200.</ref> The musicologist [[Michael Kennedy (music critic)|Michael Kennedy]] writes "One cannot call it a motto-theme, but it is an [[Idée fixe (psychology)|''idée fixe'']], and after its first quiet statement, the full orchestra repeat it ''fortissimo''. It gently subsides back to woodwind and violas and abruptly switches to D minor, an extraordinary choice of key for the first ''allegro'' of a Symphony in A flat."<ref name=k54>Kennedy, p. 54</ref> Reed speculates that Elgar's choice of D minor was a gesture against academic rules.<ref>Reed, p. 158</ref> According to the conductor [[Adrian Boult|Sir Adrian Boult]], the clashing keys arose because someone made a bet with Elgar that he could not compose a symphony in two keys at once.<ref name=k54/> It has also been speculated that the contrast was intended to represent two sides of Elgar's own personality - the successful and popular 'Bard of Empire' is heard in the noble A flat motif, set against the inner worries that continually troubled him.<ref>Stephen Johnson, notes to LSO Live recording LSO0017 (2002).</ref> The movement is in traditional [[sonata form]] with two main themes, a development and a recapitulation. It ends quietly, "an effect of magical stillness".<ref name=k55>Kennedy, p. 55</ref>
[[File:Elgar1scherzo-and-adagio.jpg|thumb|350px|left|The theme of the second movement (top) transformed in the third movement (bottom)]] The second movement is a brisk allegro. Elgar did not call it a [[scherzo]], and though Reed calls it "vivacious",<ref name=reed160>Reed, p. 160</ref> others, including Kennedy, have found it restless and even sinister in parts.<ref name=k55/> A middle section, in B{{music|flat}}, is in Elgar's ''Wand of Youth'' vein. He asked orchestras to play it "like something you hear down by the river."<ref name=k55/> As the movement draws to a close it slows down, and its first theme is transformed into the main theme of the slow movement,<ref>Excepting bar 7 of the slow movement where the top A is omitted and the shape is very slightly modified</ref> despite their contrasting tempi and different keys. According to Reed, "Someone once had the temerity to ask Elgar which version, the ''allegro'' or the ''adagio'', was written first; but the question was not very well received and the subject was not pursued."<ref name=reed162>Reed, p. 162</ref>
Kennedy says of the ''adagio'' that it is "unique among Elgar slow movements in the absence of that anguished yearning usually to be found in his quieter passages. There is no ''Angst'' here, instead a benedictory tranquillity ..."<ref name=k56>Kennedy, p. 56</ref> The second subject of the movement remains in the tranquil vein, and the movement ends in what Reed calls "the astounding effect of the muted trombones in the last five bars ... like a voice from another world."<ref name=reed162/>
The finale begins in D minor with a slow repeat of one of the subsidiary themes of the first movement, showing Elgar in "one of his most dreamy and mysterious moods."<ref name=reed162/> After the introduction there is a restless allegro, with a succession of themes including an "impulsive march-rhythm".<ref name=k56/> In a manner recalling the motivic transformation between the second and third movement, this material is later heard at half speed accompanied by harp arpeggios and with a lyrical string melody. The movement builds to a climax and ends with the ''nobilmente'' opening theme of the symphony returning "orchestrated with glittering splendour" to bring the work to a "triumphant and confident" conclusion.<ref>Kennedy, p. 57 and Reed p. 163</ref>
==Instrumentation== [[Woodwind]]s: 3 [[Flute]]s, (Fl. III doubles [[Piccolo]]), 2 [[Oboe]]s, [[English Horn]], 2 [[Clarinet]]s in A and B flat, [[Bass Clarinet]] in A and B flat, 2 [[Bassons]] and [[Contrabasson]]
[[Brass]]: 4 [[Horn (instrument)|Horn]]s in F, 3 [[Trumpet]]s in B flat, 3 [[Trombone]]s (The 3rd trombone could be a [[bass trombone]]) and [[Tuba]]
[[Percussion]]: [[Timpani]], Small [[Snare Drum]], [[Bass Drum]] and [[Cymbals]]
[[String instrument|String]]s: 2 [[Harp]]s, [[Violin]]s I and II; [[Viola]]s, [[Violoncello]]s and [[ContraBass]]es
==Duration== The composer's 1931 EMI recording of the First Symphony plays for 46 minutes and 30 seconds.<ref>EMI CD CDM 5-672-6-2: timings of the movements: I = 17:22, II = 7:37, III = 10:18, and IV = 11:13</ref> The [[BBC]]'s archives show that in a 1930 broadcast performance Elgar took 46 minutes.<ref name=cox>Cox, David, "Edward Elgar" in ''The Symphony 2: Elgar to the Present Day'', ed. Robert Simpson (1967), Penguin Books, Harmondsworth. OCLC 500339917.</ref> Elgar was noted for his brisk tempi in his own music, and later performances have been slower. Elgar's contemporaries, [[Henry Joseph Wood|Sir Henry Wood]] and [[Hamilton Harty|Sir Hamilton Harty]] took respectively 50:15 (1930) and 59:45 in 1940.<ref name=cox/> In 1972, while preparing a new recording, [[Georg Solti]] studied Elgar's 1931 performance. Solti's fast tempi, based on the composer's own, came as a shock to Elgarians accustomed to the broader tempi taken by Harty, [[John Barbirolli|Sir John Barbirolli]] and others in the mid-20th century.<ref>March, p. 431.</ref> Barbirolli's 1963 recording takes 53:53; Solti takes 48:48. Later examples of slower tempi include a 1992 recording conducted by [[Giuseppe Sinopoli]] (55:18), and a 2001 live recording conducted by [[Colin Davis|Sir Colin Davis]] (54:47).<ref>Notes to EMI CD 9689242; Decca CD 475-8226; DG CD 000289-453-1032-9; and LSO Live CD LSO 0072.</ref>
==Recordings== {{Main|Elgar Symphony No. 1 discography}} The first recording of the symphony was made by the [[London Symphony Orchestra]] in 1931, conducted by the composer for [[His Master's Voice]]. The recording was reissued on long-playing record ([[LP album|LP]]) in 1970,<ref>[http://www.gramophone.net/Issue/Page/December%201970/120/833277/ELGAR.+The+Kingdom%2C+0p.+51%E2%80%94Prelude.+Symphony+No.+1+in+A+flat+major%2C+Op.+55t.+BBC+Symphony+Orchestra%2C+tLondon+Symphony+Orchestra+both+items+conducted+by+Sir+Edward+Elgar.+World+Record+Club+it+SH139+%2825s.%29.+Recorded+11.4.1938%2C+from+HNIV+DB1934+%28234%29%2C+trecorded+2022.11.1930%2C+from+D19449+%28931%29. Reviews]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} ''[[Gramophone (magazine)|Gramophone]]'', December 1970, p. 120</ref> and on compact disc in 1992 as part of [[EMI]]'s "Elgar Edition" of all the composer's electrical recordings of his works.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120801225253/http://www.gramophone.net/Issue/Page/June%201992/92/834323/%C2%AE+Symphony+Orchestra,+bRoyal+Albert+Hall+Orchestra++Sir+Edward+Elgar.+EMI+mono+%C2%AE+CD+CDS7+545602+(three+discs:+211+minutes:+ADD).+Texts+included.+Issued+in+association+with+the+Elgar+Society+and+the+Elgar+Foundation. Reviews,] ''[[Gramophone (magazine)|Gramophone]],'' December 1992, p. 92</ref>
After 1931 the work received no further gramophone recordings until [[Adrian Boult|Sir Adrian Boult]]'s 1950 recording. During the 1950s there was only one other new recording of the symphony, and in the 1960s there were only two. In the 1970s there were four new recordings. In the 1980s there were six, and the 1990s saw twelve. Ten new recordings were released in the first decade of the 21st century.<ref name=gram>[http://www.gramophone.net Gramophone archive]</ref> Most of the recordings have been by British orchestras and conductors, but exceptions include the [[Baltimore Symphony Orchestra]], [[Stuttgart Radio Symphony Orchestra]], [[Dresden Staatskapelle]], and [[Sydney Symphony Orchestra]], and conductors [[Vladimir Ashkenazy]], [[Daniel Barenboim]], [[Bernard Haitink]], [[Tadaaki Otaka]], [[André Previn]], [[Constantin Silvestri]], Giuseppe Sinopoli, and [[Leonard Slatkin]].<ref name=gram/><ref name=march/>
[[BBC]] [[BBC Radio 3|Radio 3]]'s "Building a Library" feature, a comparative review of all available recordings, has considered the symphony three times since 1982. ''[[The Penguin Guide to Recorded Classical Music]]'', 2008 edition, contains two pages of reviews of the work. The two recordings recommended by both the BBC and ''The Penguin Guide'' are by Boult and the London Philharmonic Orchestra (1977) and [[Vernon Handley]] with the same orchestra (1979).<ref name=march>March, pp. 431–32</ref> <ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio3/building/data2/rev_593_1410.shtml "Building a Library"] BBC ''CD Review'' archive, 23 January 1982</ref>

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox book | name = The Birds of America | title_orig = The Birds of America; from original drawings by John James Audubon | translator = | image = Audubon Birds of America.jpg | caption = The cover shows a Louisiana heron,
[[Tricolored heron|''Egretta tricolor'']] (now called tricolored heron) | author = [[John James Audubon]] | illustrator = John James Audubon | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = | series = | subject = Birds – North America; Birds – pictorial works | genre = | publisher = | pub_date = 1827–1838 | media_type = | pages = 435 | isbn = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = [[Library of Congress Classification:Class Q -- Science#QL Zoology|QL674]] .A9 1827 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Birds of America''''' is a book by [[natural history|naturalist]] and painter [[John James Audubon]], containing illustrations of a wide variety of [[List of birds of the United States|birds of the United States]]. It was first published as a series in sections between 1827 and 1838, in [[Edinburgh]] and London. Not all of the specimens collected in the work were collected by Audubon himself, some were sent to him by [[John Kirk Townsend]] who had collected them on [[Nathaniel Jarvis Wyeth]]'s 1834 expedition with [[Thomas Nuttall]]. Mearns, B. & R. ''John Kirk Townsend: Collector of Audubon’s Western Birds and Mammals'' (2007). 'Narrative of a Journey Across the Rocky Mountains to the Columbia River' by John Kirk Townsend The work consists of 435 hand-coloured, life-size [[Printmaking|prints]], made from [[engraving|engraved]] plates, measuring around {{convert|39|by|26|in|cm}}. It includes images of six now-[[Extinction|extinc]]t birds: [[Carolina parakeet]], [[passenger pigeon]], [[Labrador duck]], [[great auk]], [[Eskimo curlew]], and [[Heath hen|pinnated grouse]].{{cite web|url=http://web4.audubon.org/bird/boa/ExtinctBirds.html|title=Birds Extincted since Audubon's time|first=National Audubon|last=Society|website=web4.audubon.org}} Art historians describe the quality of Audubon's work as being of high and printed with "artistic finesse." The plant-life backgrounds of some 50 of the bird studies were painted by Audubon's assistant [[Joseph Mason (artist)|Joseph Mason]] but he is not credited for his work in the book.Burt, DeVere. [http://www.ruthven.com/ruthven/CJR-SpringGrove/go "The Joseph Mason Project, Historic Spring Grove Cemetery and Arboretum"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222103914/http://www.ruthven.com/ruthven/CJR-SpringGrove/go |date=22 December 2015 }}. Ruthven.com website. Accessed 17 December 2015. He shot many specimen birds as well as transporting and maintaining supplies for Audubon.{{Cite news|url=http://historydetectives.nyhistory.org/2013/03/blast-from-the-past-everyone-needs-a-good-assistant/|title=Blast From the Past: Everyone Needs a Good Assistant|date=8 March 2013|work=History Detectives|access-date=27 November 2017|language=en-US}} Audubon also authored the companion book ''Ornithological Biographies''.{{Cite web|url=http://digital2.library.pitt.edu/collection/audubons-birds-america?f%5B0%5D=mods_typeOfResource_ms:%22text%22|title=Audubon's Birds of America|website=digital2.library.pitt.edu|access-date=27 November 2017}} ==Early publication history== [[File:1 Wild Turkey.jpg|thumbnail|left|Plate 1 by [[John James Audubon]] depicting a wild turkey, ([[Wild turkey|''Meleagris gallopavo'']]).]] About 1820, around the age of 35, Audubon declared his intention to paint every bird in North America.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/12/26/arts/antiques-central-park-s-winged-tenants-by-audubon.html|title=Central Park's Winged Tenants, By Audubon|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 December 2003}} In his bird art, he mainly forsook oil paint, the medium of serious artists of the day, in favour of [[watercolours]] and pastel crayons (and occasionally pencil, charcoal, chalk, [[gouache]], and pen and ink). As early as 1807, he developed a method of using wires and threads to hold dead birds in lifelike poses while he drew them. [[File:AudubonCarolinaParakeet2.jpg|thumbnail|upright|Audubon Carolina parakeet ([[Carolina Parakeet|''Conuropsis carolinensis'']])
now extinct]] In 1823, Audubon went to [[Philadelphia]] and New York, looking for financial support using [[Subscription business model|subscription]]s to enable him to publish his artwork. He sold the copper engraving plates through on a subscription basis in North America and Europe. Those subscribed obtained five plates at a time. Each subscriber received prints of three smaller birds, a larger bird and a mid-sized bird. The prints were produced from 1827 to 1838 that cost each subscriber around $1,000.This is equivalent to $24,600 in 2015{{Cite web|url=http://www.in2013dollars.com/1838-dollars-in-2015|title=1838 dollars in 2015 {{!}} Inflation Calculator|website=www.in2013dollars.com|language=en|access-date=27 November 2017}} It is thought that no more than 120 complete sets exist today. Each set consists of 435 individual plates that are based upon the original paintings. Each plate was engraved, printed, and hand colored by Robert Havell of London. While William Lizars, of Edinburgh, engraved the first ten plates, Havell actually finished some of those. Audubon often found support lacking. As a result, in 1826, he set sail for the United Kingdom with 250 of his original illustrations, looking for the financial support of subscribers and the technical abilities of [[Engraving|engraver]]s and printers.{{cite web|url=http://www.nls.uk/exhibitions/audubon/influence#lizars|title=Audubon and men of influence|publisher=}} After exhibiting his drawings in [[Liverpool]] and [[Manchester]], he journeyed to Edinburgh, where he met the accomplished engraver [[William H. Lizars]]. Lizars engraved up to ten of the first plates but was unable to continue the project when his colourists went on strike.{{cite web|url=http://www.liv.ac.uk/artgall/audubon/birds_of_america.htm|title=Victoria Gallery & Museum|publisher=University of Liverpool|work=liv.ac.uk}} In 1827, Audubon engaged the noted London animal engraver [[Havell family|Robert Havell Jr.]], and his father, [[Havell family|Robert Havell Sr]]. Havell Jr. oversaw the project through to its completion in 1838. [[File:Zenaida macrouraAWP17AA.jpg|thumb|upright|frameless|Carolina pigeon,
[[Mourning dove|''Zenaida macroura'']] (now called mourning dove).]] [[File:Aphelocoma coerulescens & Diospyros virginiana (Audibon).png|thumbnail|upright|''Aphelocoma coerulescens'' (Florida jay)]] The original edition of ''The Birds of America'' (sometimes called the Havell Edition{{cite web|url=http://www.minniesland.com/study_Havell_Edition.html|title=Original Audubon Prints - Antique Natural History Prints - Books - Havell - Bien - Imperial Folio - Bird and Animal Prints|work=minniesland.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619135214/http://www.minniesland.com/study_Havell_Edition.html|archivedate=19 June 2010|df=dmy-all}} after its printer, and sometimes called the [[Book size|"Double Elephant Folio"]], because of its size) was printed on handmade paper 39.5 inches tall by 28.5 inches wide. The principal printing technique was [[intaglio printing|copperplate]] etching, but engraving and [[aquatint]] were also used. Colorists applied each color in assembly-line fashion (over fifty were hired for the work).Rhodes, 2004, pp. 273, 389. Audubon funded the costly printing project through a pay-as-you-go subscription. From 1826 to 1829, he travelled around the UK and to Paris, lecturing on ornithology and frontier American life in an effort to entice wealthy patrons to subscribe to the series of prints. Subscribers included the French king [[Charles X]], the British queen [[Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen]], [[George Spencer, 2nd Earl Spencer|Lord Spencer]], and, later, the Americans [[Daniel Webster]] and [[Henry Clay]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/03/books/antiques-rarae-aves-audubon-at-auction.html|title=Rarae Aves: Audubon At Auction|newspaper=The New York Times|date=3 March 2000}} Prints were issued in sets of five every month or two in tin cases{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/25/arts/antiques-vibrant-birds-of-america-via-germany.html|title=Vibrant Birds Of America, Via Germany|newspaper=The New York Times|date=25 June 2004}} and each set usually included one very large bird, one medium-sized bird, and three small birds. The plates were published unbound and without any text to avoid having to furnish free copies to the public libraries in England. It is estimated that not more than 200 complete sets were ever compiled. An accompanying text, issued separately, was written by Audubon and the Scottish naturalist and ornithologist [[William MacGillivray]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nhm.ac.uk/nature-online/science-of-natural-history/biographies/william-macgillivray/|title=William MacGillivray|work=nhm.ac.uk}} and published in five volumes in [[Edinburgh]] between 1831 and 1839, under the title ''Ornithological Biography, or, An account of the habits of the birds of the United States of America''. The additional cost of the five volumes of text brought the total cost of plates and text to about $1000. After the folio edition was completed, Audubon decided to produce a more affordable edition and employed a lithographer from Philadelphia named J. T. Bowen. Bowen and his team created a smaller [[Octavo#Size|Royal Octavo]] edition, which was issued to subscribers in seven volumes and completed in 1844 after selling 1,199 sets.{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} Five more octavo editions were completed through 1877. The octavo edition used the text of the Ornithological biography but increased the number of plates to 500, separating some birds which had originally appeared together. Some new drawings were included, mostly by John Woodhouse though Audubon and members of Bowen's team also contributed.{{cite web |url=http://www.audubonhouse.org/audubon/octavo/bowen.cfm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100703042004/http://www.audubonhouse.org/audubon/octavo/bowen.cfm |archivedate=3 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.abirdshome.com/Audubon/VolI/00000.html|title=The Registry Of Nature Habitats - Audubon Birds of America - Publisher's Preface|work=abirdshome.com}} The Bien Edition (after [[chromolithography]] pioneer Julius Bien), was a full-sized reissue published in 1858 by Roe Lockwood in New York under the supervision of Audubon's youngest son, John Woodhouse Audubon.{{cite web|last=Flynn|first=Ron|title=The Bien Edition / The Project, Quality, Errors and Market Value|url=http://www.auduboninfo.net/articles/BIEN%20ESSAY.htm|accessdate=30 September 2012}} Due in part to the Civil War, the edition was never finished; only 15 parts of the 44 part series were completed. This edition consisted of 105 plates and included none of the original text.{{cite web|url=http://www.audubongalleries.com/guide/guide.php |title=Audubon Galleries Original Audubon Books and Prints |publisher=Audubongalleries.com |date= |accessdate=10 December 2010}} Fewer than 100 subscriptions were sold, making this edition rarer than other early editions.{{cite web|author=Ron Flynn |url=http://www.auduboninfo.net/articles/audubon_story.htm |title=About Audubon and His Octavo Edition Prints |publisher=Auduboninfo.net |date= |accessdate=10 December 2010}} Audubon's practice of obtaining his subjects has been described as:“Audubon used what we like to call today as the barrel-of-the-shotgun method...After he killed the birds, he would use a complex system of wires and strings to position the birds. Previous artists would draw the birds in a stiff position, but Audubon was different. He drew the birds in dynamic ways, by positioning them how he would observe them in the field.” ==Public exhibitions== [[File:3 Prothonotary Warbler restored.jpg|thumb|upright|Prothonotary warbler ([[Prothonotary warbler|''Protonotaria citrea'']]) in plate 3]] A full 8-volume, double-elephant folio version is on public display in the Audubon Room at the Harlan Hatcher Graduate Library at the [[University of Michigan, Ann Arbor]]. This, the first book purchased by the University, was bought in 1839 for $970 (equivalent to ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|970|1839|r=-4}}}} in {{Inflation-year|UK}}), at the time an amazing sum. The entire volume of 435 plates is also available for viewing online at the University of Michigan's website.{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.umich.edu/audubon-room/pictureit-rare-book-reader|title=PictureIt Rare Book Reader|work=umich.edu}} Since 1992, the [[Louisiana State University]] Libraries have hosted "Audubon Day," a semi-annual public showing of all four volumes of LSU's copy of the ''Birds of America.'' The set formerly belonged to one of the original subscribers, the [[Hugh Percy, 3rd Duke of Northumberland|Duke of Northumberland]], and was purchased with a grant from the Crown Zellerbach Corporation in 1964. In recent years, the event has drawn more than 200 visitors. It was profiled in a 2011 ''[[Wall Street Journal]] ''article titled "The Joys of Slow Looking."{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703421204576327750299277440|title=Birds of America by John James Audubon at Hill Memorial Library at Louisiana State University-The Joys of Slow Looking|work=Wall Street Journal|author=Willard Spiegelman|date=19 May 2011}} In 2003, the [[University of Pittsburgh]], which owns a complete collection of ''Birds of America'' that had been recently restored and preserved by the Etherington Conservation Center, mounted a major exhibition of 62 selected plates and other materials in its [[Frick Fine Arts Building#University Art Gallery|University Art Gallery]]. Following this, the university constructed an exhibit case on the ground floor of the school's [[Hillman Library]] to continuously display a rotating selection of plates to the public. Single plates have been exhibited for two weeks at a time in plate number order.{{cite web | url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/a/audubon/about.html | title=Audubon at Pitt | publisher=University Library System, University of Pittsburgh | year=2008 | accessdate=22 August 2011}} In 2007, the university undertook a project to digitize every plate from ''Birds of America'', as well as Audubon's ''Ornithological Biography'', and, for the first time, presented the complete set for public viewing through one site on the internet.{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/a/audubon/|title=Audubon's Birds of America|work=pitt.edu}}{{cite news | url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08064/862193-42.stm | title=Audubon's 'Birds' now in flock on one Web site | first=Bob | last=Hoover | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=4 March 2008 | accessdate=22 August 2011}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/art-architecture/2017/11/14/John-James-Audubon-falcons-birds-of-prey-National-Aviary-Hillman-Library/stories/201711150043|title=Free Audubon Day includes prints, lectures|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|access-date=29 November 2017|language=en}} This event, called "Audubon day" was first conducted in 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.pitt.edu/Audubon_Day_2012|title=Pitt’s University Library System Hosts Second Annual Audubon Day|publisher= University of Pittsburgh News|website=www.news.pitt.edu|language=en|access-date=29 November 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://pittnews.com/article/64902/news/birders-flock-to-audubons-art/|title=Birders flock to Audubon's art - The Pitt News|date=2 November 2015|work=The Pitt News|access-date=29 November 2017|language=en-US}} In 2007 the book was the subject of an exhibition by the [[Teylers Museum]] in [[Haarlem]], which owns a copy it ordered from the original subscription.{{cite web|url=http://www.vogelsxxl.nl/tentoonstelling.php|title=Teyler's 2007 exhibition website|date=3 November 2007|publisher=Vogelsxxl.nl|accessdate=10 December 2010}} To commemorate the book's record-breaking sale, the museum decided to display its copy (for which the museum eventually paid 2200 [[guilder]]s—a fortune at the time—during the years 1827–1838) until January 2011.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} All of Audubon's and Mason's known extant watercolors preparatory for ''Birds of America'' are housed at the [[New-York Historical Society]] in New York City.{{cite web|url=http://www.minniesland.com/study_Audubon_Art_Prints_Steiner.htm|title=Original Audubon Prints - Antique Natural History Prints - Books - Havell - Bien - Imperial Folio - Bird and Animal Prints|work=minniesland.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101111025136/http://www.minniesland.com/study_Audubon_Art_Prints_Steiner.htm|archivedate=11 November 2010|df=dmy-all}} The [[Stark Museum of Art]] in [[Orange, Texas]] owns and exhibits John James Audubon's personal copy of ''Birds of America''.{{cite web |url=http://kogt.com/Stark%20Audubon.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101216212421/http://kogt.com/Stark%20Audubon.htm |archivedate=16 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }} In 2010 the [[North Carolina Museum of Art]] began a five-year exhibition of its restored four-volume set purchased for the state by Governor [[William Alexander Graham]] in 1846.{{cite web|url=http://www.ncartmuseum.org/exhibitions/audubon|title=Exhibitions|work=ncartmuseum.org}} [[Liverpool Central Library]] currently has a copy of ''Birds of America'' on display in a glass case, with its pages turned weekly,{{cite web|url=http://www.sevenstreets.com/city-living/refurbishment-liverpool-central-library/ |title=Rekindling Liverpool Central Library |publisher=Sevenstreets.com |accessdate=24 January 2013}} as well as being displayed through an [[interactive kiosk]], allowing readers to view the contents close-up without damaging the original copy using an Evoke Ev5 Kiosk.{{cite web|url=http://www.evoke-kiosks.co.uk/news/the-book-and-the-kiosk.aspx|title=The book and the kiosk|work=evoke-kiosks.co.uk}} One of the original books was bought by [[Laurance Spelman Rockefeller]], who had each plate individually framed. They are all hanging throughout the public areas of the Woodstock Inn, in Woodstock, Vermont, which he built in 1969.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} Paisley Museum and Art Gallery, in [[Paisley, Renfrewshire|Paisley]] Scotland has the four volume elephant folio of Birds of America.{{Cite web|title = Prize possessions on show at Paisley museum|url = http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/prize-possessions-show-paisley-museum-6819388|website = dailyrecord|accessdate = 3 December 2015}} The [[Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Glasgow|Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons]] in Glasgow, Scotland holds one volume which is on display in the library, together with an interactive version.{{Cite web|title = Doors Open Day 2015|url = http://libraryblog.rcpsg.ac.uk/2015/08/28/doors-open-day-2015/|website = College Library|accessdate = 3 December 2015}} ==Collections and archives== Though individual prints are commonly available, only one hundred twenty complete sets are known to exist. One complete copy of ''The Birds of America'' exists as part of [[The Darlington Collection]] at the [[University of Pittsburgh]].{{cite web|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/art-architecture/2013/11/17/University-of-Pittsburgh-exhibits-Audubon-prints/stories/201311170047|title=Pitt exhibits Audubon prints|publisher=Pittsburgh Post Gazette|last=Pitz |first=Marylynne |date= 16 November 2013|access-date= 27 November 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://audubon.pitt.edu/|title=Audubon's Birds of America at the University of Pittsburgh|website=audubon.pitt.edu|access-date=27 November 2017}} Another complete collection is housed with [[Meisei University]] in Tokyo, Japan.{{Cite web|url=http://birdsofamerica.meisei-u.ac.jp/|title=Meisei University Birds Of America, Meisei University|last=|first=|date=|website=birdsofamerica.meisei-u.ac.jp|access-date=27 November 2017}} ''The Birds of America'' is on permanent display in [[Trinity College (Connecticut)|Trinity College's]] Watkinson Library, and was owned by the engraver, Robert Havell. It was donated to the College in 1900 by Gurdon Wadsworth Russell, an 1834 graduate of Trinity.{{Cite web|url=http://www.trincoll.edu/NewsEvents/NewsArticles/pages/Birds.aspx|title=Trinity College is Nest for Birders|last=Webmaster|website=www.trincoll.edu|access-date=1 October 2016}} [[Toronto Public Library]] also holds a copy; originally a four-volume set, it was unbound to preserve the individual plates which have been digitized in the library’s [https://www.torontopubliclibrary.ca/search.jsp?Erp=20&N=38537+4294831200&Ntt=Audubon&view=grid Digital Archive] and stored in custom-made boxes in the Toronto Reference Library.{{Cite web|url=http://omeka.tplcs.ca/virtual-exhibits/exhibits/show/audubon/tpl-copy|title=Birds of America at the Toronto Public Library · John J. Audubon’s Birds of America · TPL Virtual Exhibits|website=omeka.tplcs.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-11}} Another complete copy of the prints, bound in 17 volumes, belongs to the [[Library of Parliament]] in [[Ottawa]], Canada.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/john-james-audubon-birds-library-parliament-digitize-1.3838474|title=Library of Parliament digitized John James Audubon bird masterpiece {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-10-26|language=en-US}} ==Recent sales== In March 2000 Sheikh [[Collecting practices of the Al-Thani Family|Saud Al-Thani of Qatar purchased]] a copy of ''The Birds of America'' at a [[Christie's]] auction for $8.8 million, a record for any book at auction.{{cite web|url=http://www.artandantiquesmag.com/2009/02/call-of-the-wild/|title=John James Audubon's 'Birds Of America' Sells for $8.8 Million|work=Art & Antiques Magazine}} In December 2010, ''[[The Economist]]'' magazine estimated that, adjusted for inflation, five of the ten highest prices ever paid for printed books were paid for copies of ''The Birds of America''.{{cite news| url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2010/12/books | work=The Economist | title=Book value | date=8 December 2010}} Of the 120 copies known to survive, only thirteen are held in private collections.{{cite web|last=Collett |first=Mike |url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/40547140 |title=Rare 'Birds of America' book fetches $11.5M at auction|publisher=Today.msnbc.msn.com |date= |accessdate=10 December 2010}} In March 2000 the Fox-Bute copy sold at Christie's, New York, for $8,802,500.[[BBC]], 9 September 2010, [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11242275 World's most expensive book goes back on sale]{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/shakespeare-first-edition-breaks-sothebys-record-with-16328m-sale-407861.html|title=Shakespeare first edition breaks Sotheby's record with £2.8m salet|work=The Independent}} In December 2005 an unbound copy, the Providence Athenaeum Set, sold, again at Christie's, New York, for $5.6 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704635704575604751410902906|title=Collectors Circle as 'Birds of America' Comes to Auction at Sotheby's|author=Ellen Gamerman|date=26 November 2010|work=Wall Street Journal}} On 6 December 2010, a complete copy of the first edition was sold in London at [[Sotheby's]] for £7,321,250 (approximately $11.5 million){{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-12-07/aristocrats-seeking-cash-boost-119-million-old-master-auctions-in-london.html | work=Bloomberg | first=Scott | last=Reyburn | title=‘Birds of America' Book Fetches Record $11.5 Million | date=7 December 2010}} during the sale of Magnificent Books, Manuscripts and Drawings from the Collection of Frederick, [[Frederick Fermor-Hesketh, 2nd Baron Hesketh|Second Lord Hesketh]]. The winning bid was a record auction price for a printed book and was placed by London-based art dealer [[Edward Tollemache#Courtier|Michael Tollemache]], who outbid three others during the auction. According to the [[provenance]] details reported by the auction house, the copy's original owner was [[Henry Witham]] of Durham, listed as subscriber 11 in Audubon's ''Ornithological Biography''; the first volume of the set bears a presentation inscription from Witham's wife, dated 24 June 1831.{{cite web| publisher= [[Sotheby's]] |url= http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/2010/magnificent-books-manuscripts-and-drawings-from-the-collection-of-frederick-2nd-lord-hesketh-l10413/overview.html| title= Lot 50: The Birds of America; from original drawings by John James Audubon. London: published by the author, 1827–1838 | accessdate=10 December 2010}} Lord Hesketh had bought the copy from a descendant of Witham at a [[Christie's]] auction on 3 July 1951, paying £7,000. On 20 January 2012 a complete copy of the first edition was sold by heirs of the [[William Bentinck, 4th Duke of Portland|Fourth Duke of Portland]] at Christie's, New York, for $7.9 million. The buyer was identified only as "an American collector who bid by phone." The sale brought to 120 the number of copies known to have survived – 107 in institution collections and 13 in private hands.{{cite news |title=Audubon's ‘Birds' sells for $7.9M |agency=Associated Press |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-01-20/news/30649241_1_species-first-edition-audubon |newspaper=New York Daily News |date=20 January 2012 |accessdate=1 May 2012}} ==Plates== File:61 Great Horned Owl.jpg|Great horned owl

 [[c:User:Mturtle/The_Birds_of_America|Gallery of the rest of the plates.]] ==Textiles== [[File:Audubon fabric.jpg|thumb|Furnishing fabric, from [[Lancashire]], 1830s]] In 1830s, immediately after the publication, several plates were used as a basis for the design of a series of roller-printed furnishing fabric, produced in [[Lancashire]], United Kingdom.{{cite web|title=Furnishing fabric, Lancashire, 1830s, Victoria and Albert Museum, CIRC.305-1956|url=https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O115037/furnishing-fabric/|accessdate=23 February 2012}} ==See also== * [[List of most expensive books and manuscripts]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em|refs={{cite web| url= http://lccn.loc.gov/06018534 | title= The birds of America; from original drawings | publisher= [[Library of Congress]] | accessdate= 10 December 2010}} }} ==Bibliography== * Rhodes, Richard (2004).
